HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
A Big Find For the Met
 When one thinks of artists' responses to the horrors of war in the 20th century, Picasso's "Guernica" generally comes to mind first, then the allegories of Max Beckmann. 
 After Labor Day, when the second floor of the Metropolitan Museum's modern-art galleries reopen after a summer of repairs and renovations, visitors can see another artist's response to the war of his time.
"Being With" (1946), a reaction to World War II by the Chilean-born Surrealist painter Roberto Matta, will hang on a wall by itself. This large canvas (180 by 87 inches) depicts an inferno of sorts with robotic, mutant, almost skinless creatures. Some of their arms are bound; some have been splayed or tortured or have their heads encased in wire. 
This painting is one of the museum's latest acquisitions. "He'd obviously seen 'Guernica,' " said William S. Lieberman, chairman of the Met's Modern art department.
Mr. Lieberman, a former curator at the Museum of Modern Art, knows the painting well. In 1947 the Modern included it in a show called "Large-Scale Modern Paintings."
"It was the first time the Abstract Expressionist painters had seen easel painting this large," Mr. Lieberman said. "They were more used to murals that size."
A decade later "Being With" was shown at the Modern again, this time in a retrospective of Matta's work organized by William S. Rubin, then the chief curator of paintings and sculpture at the Modern. After that, Mr. Lieberman said, he heard the painting went to Switzerland.
"I thought it had been lost," he said.
But one day, when Mr. Lieberman was having lunch with Danny Berger, a consultant to the Met, Mr. Berger mentioned that he had seen the painting and that it belonged to Jeffrey H. Loria, a Manhattan art dealer who also owns the Florida Marlins baseball team. "I hotfooted it over to his office, and by God, there it was," Mr. Lieberman said. The museum bought the painting, which experts said could be worth up to $500,000, with two acquisition funds.
The painting is the first important work by Matta to enter the Met's collection. Other holdings of his work include a drawing from 1942 and a small painting from 1949.

From War to 'Peace'
On Aug. 18, "Peace," a large bell modeled after those found in Chinese temples, with a gilded life-size cast of the Chinese artist Zhang Huan's naked body hanging next to it, will be installed on the plaza of the Ritz-Carlton in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Zhang Huan, who created the work, inscribed the names of his ancestors from his native village inside the bell. 
Viewers may ring the bell not with a gong, but with the sculpture of Mr. Zhang Huan's body, as a symbolic way of forcing a confrontation between the artist and his past.
"We have been following Zhang's work for a while, and his proposal stood out as the strongest" candidates for that space, said Anne Pasternak, executive director of Creative Time, the public arts organization presenting the project with the Ritz-Carlton and the Battery Park City Authority.
During the first week in October the artist will stage a performance with 25 Buddhist Shaolin kung fu practitioners from a temple in Flushing, Queens. While Mr. Zhang Huan hangs inside the bell, the others will demonstrate traditional forms of kung fu.

Shuttered in Brooklyn
Forget about going to the Brooklyn Museum of Art for the next two weeks. From Monday through Aug. 19, it will be closed and its 300 employees will be furloughed for one of the two weeks. Employees will rotate in shifts so everyone won't be gone at the same time. 
The museum was forced to close because of city budget cuts for the new fiscal year, museum officials said. When the closing was announced in May, the museum thought its budget would be cut by more than $2.4 million.
But now, because of changes to the budget, the reduction is only $836,700, on top of previous cuts made since 9/11. While that figure is significantly lower than anticipated, it is still big enough to close down an institution suffering, like most New York museums, from less private philanthropy and foundation support during the poor economy.
Staff members said they were depressed about losing a week's pay and at seeing the exhibition schedule reduced.
Many also wondered why the museum was selectively adding employees when it could not afford to pay the ones it already had, and why the museum hired an image consultant at great expense to "make it a more visitor-friendly museum," as one employee said, speaking on condition of anonymity.

A Modern Moment
So eager are curators at the Museum of Modern Art to show off their collections while the museum's Manhattan home is closed for expansion that it will be showing selected objects from its architecture and design collection at the International Art + Design Fair. 
"They gave us some space and we're assembling the objects," said Terence Riley, the museum's chief curator of architecture and design. "Except for the car show at MoMA QNS, nothing from our department has been on view for four years." The design galleries were among the first to be shut when the museum began construction.
That the museum would agree to show at a commercial fair held annually at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan is not as surprising as it might seem. The opening-night gala on Sept. 24 just happens to be a benefit for the Modern's architecture and design department.
"It's at the main crossing, so it is not in the middle of the commercial space," Mr. Riley said.
The show will be chronological, beginning with an elevator grille designed by Louis Sullivan for the Chicago Stock Exchange, built in 1893-94 and demolished in 1972. Also on view will be the first car to enter the museum's collection: the Italian Cisitalia "202" GT designed by Pinin Farina in 1946. Several chairs will be shown, including the Vermelha chair, created by the Brazilians Fernando and Humberto Campaga in 1993, and the Sandows Chair, by the French designer Rene Herbst, from 1928.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Being With," a response to World War II by Roberto Matta in 1946, is a new Met acquisition. (Photo by Metropolitan Museum of Art)

HEADLINE: British Airways Posts Quarterly Loss 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 31 

 BODY:
Just one day after it resolved a costly labor dispute, British Airways reported its worst quarterly loss today and said a major strike in mid-July would cost up to $65 million.
 Like other airlines, British Airways, the largest European airline, has lost business because of the war in Iraq, the effect of the SARS virus on air travel and a general economic slowdown, even as low-cost airlines like EasyJet and Ryanair lure European passengers with low fares. (Ryanair offered tickets from Stansted Airport near London to Eindhoven in the Netherlands for as little as $3.20, plus taxes.) 
 British Airways said today that its net loss for the first quarter ended June 30 was $:63 million ($101.5 million), in contrast to a net profit of $:40 million in the period a year ago. Not only that, it said a wildcat strike by check-in staff at Heathrow Airport in mid-July would cost up to $65 million. Analysts said the strike could tip the airline's annual loss to its worst since it became private 16 years ago. 
Rod Eddington, the chief executive, said on a conference call today that the strike was "terrible for customers, terrible for B.A. staff and terrible for the business."
The walkout forced the cancellation of 500 flights in a dispute over the introduction of an electronic swipe-card for staff to clock in and out of work. The airline and labor unions agreed to a compromise settlement to the dispute this week.
Mr. Eddington said the newest losses resulted from "the most testing period in aviation history," but insisted that British Airways would not be distracted from a major cost-cutting effort that has trimmed over 11,000 jobs since August 2001.
European airlines are expected to report losses of up to $2.5 billion this year, but many analysts said British Airways is cutting costs more decisively than its European rivals.
Despite the losses reported today, the company's share price rose as investors took heart from an assurance by Mr. Eddington that the company would meet its cost-cutting targets.
Recovery "is going to happen first and faster than at other airlines," said Andrew Light, an analyst at the Smith Barney unit of Citigroup, while the losses were as steep as some analysts were expecting earlier this month.
According to British Airways, some $:79 million of losses resulted from a single write-off associated with the sale of its Deutsche BA subsidiary last year. The company acknowledged, however, that first- quarter sales fell 11 percent, to $:1.8 billion as it lowered fares to lure customers after the war in Iraq.
British Airways seeks the bulk of its revenue from high-end business travelers, mainly on the trans-Atlantic route to the United States. "You have got an aggressive restructuring that, if anything, is ahead of plan," Mr. Light said. "Already the Atlantic route is doing quite well and the rise in the stock markets and corporate earnings suggests that business travel should start to recover."
British Airways said its costs in the first quarter were 5.4 percent lower than one year ago and it is on track for further cost reductions by March 2005.
Andrew Green, a fund manager at SG Asset Management, said investors had looked beyond today's losses partly because the Deutsche BA write-down was a "book loss" while British Airways itself was cutting costs despite higher fuel bills and generating cash.
"You are getting all that when the aviation cycle is at its lowest and the only way is up from here," he said. "It's a bit of an abnormal period and people don't expect conditions to be like this again."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares End Losing Streak on Word of Stronger Growth

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street advanced yesterday on news that the economy grew at a much stronger pace than was expected in the second quarter and that new jobless-benefits claims fell for a third consecutive week.
 The market also rose for the month of July. Its standout achiever was the Nasdaq composite index, which climbed for a sixth consecutive month -- a feat not seen in eight years. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index completed a five-month winning stretch, something they had not accomplished since 1999.
Upbeat earnings from Exxon Mobil and Procter & Gamble contributed to the advance yesterday, the market's first in four days. Stocks did pull back from sharper gains in the last two hours of trading. Such late-afternoon retreats are common on the last trading day of the month, when portfolio managers make adjustments to maximize returns and look good to shareholders.
After climbing as much as 197.97 points in earlier trading, the Dow closed up 33.75 points, or 0.4 percent, at 9,233.80. The gain erased some of the 84.52 points lost in the previous three sessions. The broader market was also higher. The Nasdaq rose 14.11 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,735.02, and the S.& P. advanced 2.82 points, or 0.3 percent, to 990.31.
The Nasdaq rose 6.9 percent in July, its sixth monthly gain. The last time the Nasdaq had a streak that long was the 10-month period from December 1994 through September 1995. For the month, the Dow rose 2.8 percent and the S.& P. added 1.6 percent. July was the fifth consecutive winning month for the two gauges, something last seen in the five-month period that ended January 1999.
The Commerce Department said the economy as measured by gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the second quarter, well ahead of the 1.5 percent pace economists had forecast.
The Labor Department said new applications filed last week for unemployment benefits fell 3,000, to a five-month low of 388,000. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago also reported encouraging data on manufacturing in the Midwest. The group's index of area business activity rose to 55.9 in July, on a seasonally adjusted basis, from 52.5 in June, according to Dow Jones.
A reading above 50 signals that manufacturing is expanding. The July reading exceeded analysts' forecast of 53.8.
Good earnings news also lifted the market. Exxon Mobil advanced 26 cents, to $35.58, on second-quarter profits that surpassed Wall Street's estimate by 6 cents a share.
Procter & Gamble rose 12 cents, to $87.87, on fiscal fourth-quarter profits that were a penny a share higher than analysts had predicted.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Prices Fall
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasuries tumbled yesterday, pushing 10-year-note yields to their highest level in a year, after a government report showed second-quarter growth exceeded economists' forecasts. Declines were exacerbated by investors' selling Treasuries to protect against mortgage-related losses.
The 10-year note finished its worst month since May 1984.
"The bubble has burst," said Robert DeLucia, managing director and chief economist at Cigna Retirement and Investment Services in Hartford, with $80 billion of assets. "We're clearly in a bear market for Treasuries."
By late in the day, the benchmark 10-year note fell 24/32, to a price of 93 26/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.41 percent from 4.31 percent on Wednesday.
And the 30-year bond dropped 1 19/32, to 100 8/32. Its yield jumped to 5.36 percent from 5.25 percent.

HEADLINE: Illinois Court Drops Order to Raise Judges' Pay 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 31 

 BODY:
The Illinois Supreme Court vacated today its order that the state give its judges cost-of-living increases, leaving a trial court to decide the issue instead. 
 The court also dropped its demand that Daniel W. Hynes, the state comptroller, defend himself against a possible contempt charge for failing to administer the increases. 
 This afternoon, paychecks with the lower salaries were sent. 
The Supreme Court ruling defuses the controversy that had been mounting for a week between the judicial and executive branches of state government, though it does not resolve the underlying question of whether the 900 judges in the state will be given a 2.8 percent raise. That would add about $4,000 to the seven Supreme Court justices' $158,000 salaries. Other judges earn more than $127,000. 
Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich vetoed the $3.8 million in increases this month, citing the state's $5 billion shortfall. State judges, though, have sued the governor, contending that a legislative resolution from 1990 requires cost-of-living increases for judges and that leaving salaries unchanged despite inflation violates the state Constitution by effectively diminishing the judges' pay. 
"They decided to be less imperialistic about this and go with some due process," said Cheryle Jackson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Blagojevich.
"The court today took one step, one good step, by ending their attempt to unilaterally order themselves pay increases," Ms. Jackson said. "Now they should take the next step, think about public good, and end their lawsuits to give themselves a pay raise in the worst fiscal crisis in our state's history."
The court retreated after State Attorney General Lisa Madigan had filed a motion saying the justices had acted outside their jurisdiction in ordering Mr. Hynes to issue paychecks with unsecure financing to issue paychecks with unsecure financing and to appear before them to explain himself. The motion did not deal with the cost-of-living adjustments, commonly known as cola's.
"We believe that the best way to address the questions about the judges' cola's is through a judicial proceeding in a trial court," a spokeswoman for Ms. Madigan, Melissa Merz, said. "That is the most appropriate vehicle."
A spokesman for the court, Joe Tybor, declined to discuss the issue. 
Mr. Hynes's spokeswoman, Karen Craven, said he "has always felt that a legal action filed in the appropriate jurisdiction with proper notice is the way to resolve this issue, and today's order accomplishes that."

HEADLINE: Motorola Wins $4 Billion in Dispute Over Loans to Turkish Family 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Motorola won a $4.26 billion fraud judgment yesterday against members of a wealthy Turkish family who got loans from Motorola to expand a cellular phone company.
 Motorola lent more than $2 billion to the Uzan family for the phone venture. Nokia of Finland, a co-plaintiff, lent $700 million. The ruling said that at least $1 billion was diverted to other companies controlled by the family for spending on luxury items and for their personal accounts. 
 In addition to the financial award to Motorola, Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan ordered the Uzans, who control Telsim, Turkey's second-largest cellphone company, to turn over more than 66 percent of Telsim's stock to the finance unit of Motorola and 7.5 percent of the shares to Nokia. 
Judge Rakoff said the shares were pledged to an Uzan company that held them on behalf of Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., and Nokia as collateral for the loans. The Uzans, working with associates and companies they controlled, later arranged for Telsim to issue new stock to dilute those shares without notifying Motorola or Nokia and then stripped them of voting rights to prevent their taking control of Telsim when the loans were not repaid, according to the ruling.
The case was tried under Illinois laws that did not allow Judge Rakoff directly to order a cash judgment for Nokia. But Judge Rakoff ruled that the Uzans would owe Nokia $1.71 billion, or twice the amount of the unpaid loans and interest owed if they did not transfer the stock within a week of the judgment becoming final. 
"They have sought to advance and conceal their scheme through an almost endless series of lies, threats and chicanery," Judge Rakoff said.
The Uzans, who did not appear at the trial in February, said yesterday that they would appeal the decision and expected it to be reversed by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. 
The Uzans have argued that the entire conflict reflects their suppliers' unwillingness to face up to the losses stemming from the global crash in the telecommunications markets, recession in Turkey and a large devaluation of the Turkish lira. They said the main issue was whether Telsim's problems were beyond their control and that the terms of the agreements called for arbitration of such issues in Switzerland. 
The ruling was the latest milestone in a worldwide legal battle. Last week, a court in Geneva said that it had not seen enough evidence that Motorola was defrauded to warrant freezing Uzan assets in its jurisdiction. A number of other courts, including a Swiss court, in Zurich, had backed the efforts by Motorola and Nokia to attach assets, although not always to the full extent they requested. 
The Uzans, whose family fortune was estimated last year by Forbes magazine at $1.3 billion, began with a construction company founded by Kemal Uzan. The empire, now run primarily by his sons, Marat Hakan Uzan and Cem Cengiz Uzan, includes major investments in finance, media, utilities and industrial companies. Their holdings also include real estate, including at least seven apartments in New York.
Motorola hopes to begin liquidating Uzan assets it controls in the United States and Britain as soon as the 10-day period to seek a stay elapses, according to Howard Stahl, a lawyer for the company. Those assets are valued at $40 million to $50 million. The Uzans have not yet decided whether to try to stop the sales, according to R. Stan Mortenson, a lawyer working for them.
Judge Rakoff's ruling gives Motorola permission to go after every entity controlled by the Uzans, not just the family members and the three companies named as defendants in the suit. But, given all the room left for further legal maneuvering, Motorola may be the least of the Uzans' current worries.
Their far-reaching empire in Turkey has been under severe pressure because of growing conflicts with the Turkish government, which has seized two power plants operated by Uzan-controlled utilities and the bank that is the centerpiece of the Uzan financial holdings. 
Cem Uzan, 43, is the leader of the Youth Party, which has been gaining ground in Turkish politics. But his attacks on Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan have given the government added incentive to pursue longstanding complaints about the family's business practices. Family members who were stakeholders in the seized bank have been barred from leaving the country. 
Motorola and Nokia have both written off the full value of their investments. Motorola said it had not yet determined how it would treat any money it might recover. Motorola's shares, which surged briefly past $10 in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange, settled back to end at $9.04. Nokia's shares, which trade most heavily on the Helsinki stock exchange in its home country of Finland, hit a peak of $15.46 when trading in New York began but closed at $15.30, up 2 cents.

HEADLINE: Some Exemptions Are Proposed on Predatory Lending Laws 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency issued proposed regulations yesterday that are expected to exempt national banks from many state laws against predatory lending, including those in New York and New Jersey.
 While the comptroller made no ruling on the predatory lending laws in New York and New Jersey, the proposal would exempt national banks from provisions that are similar to those in the two states. 
 The regulations, which could be approved in several months after a comment period, would permit the comptroller to give "a very quick response" to a request from a national bank for exemption from the New York and New Jersey laws, a spokesman said. That ruling would then apply to all national banks. State-chartered banks and mortgage lenders would still be subject to the laws. 
The comptroller also proposed a standard on predatory lending. The proposed rule "would prohibit national banks from making loans that they cannot reasonably expect to be repaid without recourse to the borrower's collateral."
But, in a statement, John D. Hawke Jr., the comptroller, said, "We have no evidence that national banks are engaged in predatory lending practices."
Yesterday's action by the comptroller brought immediate criticism from Diana L. Taylor, the superintendent of banks in New York.
"I am concerned because this is an unelected official in Washington who is overruling state legislators by regulatory fiat," she said. "The state legislature has a better idea of the consumer situation in the state than an unelected official in Washington."
Maude Hurd, the national president of Acorn, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, said: "To a homeowner, there's no difference between a predatory loan that comes from a national bank subsidiary or from a mortgage company. They lose huge amounts of their equity and are locked into excessive interest rates just the same."
She also said, "Contrary to what the banks claim, there is evidence that national banks and their subsidiaries have been involved in predatory lending."
The proposed regulations came as the comptroller specifically exempted national banks from the predatory lending law in Georgia. That decision came on a request made in February by an Indiana bank.
Efforts by states to enact predatory lending laws have been running into obstacles all year.
A principal obstacle has been restrictions by credit agencies on their ratings for pools of mortgages from the states with predatory lending laws. These restrictions make it harder to resell in the secondary market the so-called high-cost mortgages that are most likely to violate predatory lending laws, restricting access to such loans.
But the comptroller's decision could make it possible for the rating agencies to give credit ratings to mortgage pools with high-cost loans originated by national banks in Georgia and in other states once they are exempted from the state laws. Adam M. Tempkin, a spokesman for Standard & Poor's, said the comptroller's statement was being reviewed.
The comptroller's action comes after a similar move by the federal Office of Thrift Supervision, which exempted federal savings associations from the predatory lending laws in New York and New Jersey. The law in New York City is being challenged by the Bloomberg administration and is not yet in effect.
The comptroller and the Office of Thrift Supervision together are close to achieving the goal of legislation filed in the House earlier this year that would permit federal law to overrule state laws on predatory lending.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
On 10th Avenue, a Boom in Apartments

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
A residential no man's land three years ago, 10th Avenue from West 48th to West 56th Streets has sprouted three mixed-income apartment buildings in three years, and more housing is planned.
 The buildings have a total of 702 rental apartments that have been leased or are being leased. At each building, 80 percent of the units are rented at market rates, and the rest are reserved for low- and moderate-income families. 
 Six hundred more mixed-income residences in two towers are planned as part of the redevelopment over the next three years of two city-owned sites that cut an L-shaped swath from 51st to 53rd Streets. But the developer, the Dermot Company, is not certain if the units will all be rentals or a mix of condominiums and rentals. 
In front of those planned towers a cluster of former tenement buildings along 10th Avenue at 51st and 52nd Streets have been or will be rehabilitated by the nonprofit Clinton Housing Development Corporation, producing 39 apartments for low-income families.
Nancy Packes, president of Halstead/Feathered Nest Leasing Consultant, said the activity is a "natural extension" of the development of the last two decades along Eighth and Ninth Avenues. On Eighth, five apartment complexes with 2,105 rentals have been completed or are under way, while Ninth has filled with restaurants, clubs and boutiques.
"It is always a question of expansion around a nucleus," Ms. Packes said.
In 2001, when the Gotham Organization opened the 222-apartment Foundry, the first of the 10th Avenue rentals, on a site between 54th and 55th Streets, the area was "a chockablock of industrial buildings, car dealerships and studios," said David L. Picket, Gotham's president. 
But, he added, it was just a matter of time before the activity from Ninth Avenue spilled over to 10th Avenue, where there were sites to develop.
Mr. Picket's company is also developing a 150-apartment rental on Ninth Avenue at 55th Street, where an empty Food Emporium once stood.
Anthony Borelli, district manager of Community Board 4, said much of the recent activity is in the Clinton Urban Renewal Area, from 50th to 56th Streets and 10th to 11th Avenues, and "that's progress," but the hope "is to strike a balance" with preservation.
Height restrictions are in place from 41st to 59th Streets and from Eighth Avenue to the river, and they limit new midblock buildings to seven stories or 66 feet to blend with existing structures. But on the corner, buildings can be as high as the underlying zoning allows.
In Manhattan's still sluggish rental market, the developers of the 10th Avenue buildings are using different strategies to woo new tenants and retain existing ones. 
The latest building to begin leasing is the Westport, with 371 apartments, which the Related Companies is developing at West 56th Street. Rents for the studio to two-bedroom apartments in Related's building are $1,995 to $4,695 a month, said Nicole Berlyn, the company's director of marketing. 
She said Related has offered incentives like one-month free rent since leasing at the 27-story building began in June and so far has leased 150 units. Ms. Berlyn attributed the pace of leasing, in part to "the energy of an up-and-coming neighborhood."
There are no incentives at the Clinton, the seven-story, 109-apartment midblock building on 48th Street, which the Brooklyn-based Hudson Companies has developed with partners. Instead, David Kramer, a Hudson principal, said, "We set our rents slightly under those of the other new buildings in the neighborhood." 
He said that since leasing began in March, all but one of the studio to two-bedroom apartments have been leased at rents of $1,395 to $3,400 a month.
Mr. Picket said the Foundry's rents had dropped 10 to 15 percent compared with original prices for most of the studio to two-bedroom units, which now lease for $1,700 to $3,500 a month. As for incentives, he said, "We offer free rent or lower rent depending on if the tenant is new or existing."
Last March the Dermot Company was selected by the city to redevelop the sites on 51st to 53rd Streets. Stephen N. Benjamin, a Dermot principal, said it plans to also have 40,000 square feet of retail and community space, including a health club, an arts center and a park. The $200 million redevelopment is to be called Clinton Green, in part because it will incorporate "green" building principles.
"Tenth Avenue is a desirable place to live today," Mr. Benjamin said. "With Clinton Green we will build on that foundation."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Judge Finds I.B.M. Violated Age Discrimination Laws
A federal court has ruled that I.B.M. violated age discrimination laws when it converted its traditional pension plan to more controversial types, casting doubt over similar changes in pension plans covering millions of workers.
 Judge G. Patrick Murphy ruled that I.B.M. had discriminated against its older workers in several ways when it converted its pension plan because the changes left them with smaller benefits at retirement than younger workers would receive. Page A1. 

Verizon Strike Could Affect Service
If unions representing 78,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast go on strike this weekend, the company insists service will not suffer. But past experience is not on management's side. When the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers went on strike in 2000, disruptions were numerous. C3.

About 2,400 orders for phone-line installations on Long Island have gone unfilled as workers scramble to respond to a glut of repair orders, according to union leaders. C3.

Consumers Adopt Digital Products
Consumers are increasingly turning to all sorts of digital gadgets and services -- cameras, music players, videodisc players, TV's, cellphones, instant messaging, e-mail, online shopping, high-speed Internet access. A1.

Motorola Wins a Fraud Judgment
Motorola won a $4.26 billion fraud judgment in federal court against members of a Turkish family who got loans from Motorola to expand a cellular phone company. C3.

Revenue Falls at Vivendi Universal
Vivendi Universal reported second-quarter revenue fell drastically, further complicating its much-scrutinized auction to sell its United States entertainment assets. C12.

British Air Posts a 1st-Quarter Loss
British Airways reported a first-quarter loss of $:63 million ($101.5 million), in contrast to a net profit of $:40 million. It also said that a wildcat strike in mid-July would cost up to $65 million. Rod Eddington, the chief executive, called the strike "terrible for customers, terrible for B.A. staff and terrible for the business." World Business, Section W.

Regulator May Change Bank Rules
The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency issued proposed regulations that are expected to exempt national banks from many state laws against predatory lending. C5.

Stocks Rise on Strong Growth Data
Wall Street advanced on news that the economy grew at a much stronger pace than was expected in the second quarter. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.75 points, to 9,233.80. The Nasdaq composite gained 14.11 points, to 1,735.02, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 2.82 points, to 990.31. C5.

Comcast Narrows 2nd-Quarter Loss
Comcast posted a narrower second-quarter loss and reported solid revenue gains. C2.

Disney Beats Earnings Estimates
Walt Disney reported a 10 percent increase in profits, beating analysts' expectations. C2.

HEADLINE: Faster 2nd-Quarter Growth Fuels Optimism 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The United States economy threw off its sluggish growth in the second quarter and expanded at a 2.4 percent annual rate, pulled up by rising military and consumer spending and, at long last, a revival in business investment in computers and software, the government reported yesterday.
 The spring upturn has nearly every forecaster, even the pessimists among them, signing on to the proposition that the national economy is finally breaking out of the weak, jobless recovery that has lasted for 18 months. A surge in growth is expected for the rest of the year. What is uncertain is whether it will last into 2004 or whether the economy will drop back into weakness. 
 "If we can go from an economy driven by discount pricing and mortgage refinancing to one driven by job creation and income growth, that will keep the upturn going, and there is some evidence that is starting to happen," said James W. Paulsen, the chief investment strategist for Wells Capital Management, who considers himself a cautious optimist. 
The second-quarter performance stood in contrast to the two previous quarters, in which the gross domestic product, the most popular measure of the nation's output of goods and services, rose at a weak annual rate of 1.4 percent. 
The hope among the forecasters is that the rebound will be strong enough to push economic growth to a sustained annual rate of at least 3.5 percent -- enough to end months of constant job losses and make payrolls increase again. Since the start of the recovery, in November 2001, economic growth has averaged only 2.6 percent a year, and the latest report suggested that the second-quarter strength came mainly from spending that might not last.
The second quarter, from April through June, included the war with Iraq and featured the largest rise in military spending since the fall of 1951, in the midst of the Korean War. Then the quarterly rise was 110 percent; this time it was 44 percent, the Bureau of Economic Analysis reported. The jump in military spending contributed 1.69 percentage points to second-quarter G.D.P. growth, or 70 percent of the total rise. Economists questioned whether such growth in military spending could be sustained over subsequent quarters.
The next-largest contributor to growth in G.D.P. was a 3.3 percent rise in consumer spending. Stepped-up purchases of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans accounted for a third of that increase. Low interest rates and cash-back incentives stimulated the vehicle sales, along with spending money freed up through mortgage refinancing.
The boom in mortgage refinancing may be coming to an end, however. With expectations growing for a stronger economy, interest rates are rising. The 10-year Treasury note, to which many mortgage rates are tied, has risen by 1.3 percentage points since June 13, to 4.41 percent.
"The backup in interest rates will cause us to lose the support from mortgage refinancing by early next year, and that will sap the economy's momentum," said William Dudley, the chief domestic economist at Goldman, Sachs. "It suggests that the robustness may not prove sustainable." Mr. Dudley nevertheless predicted the economy would expand at a 3.5 percent annual growth rate through the rest of this year.
Three other reports, also released yesterday, contributed to the optimism. New applications for unemployment benefits dropped by 3,000 last week, to a five-month low of 388,000. The Employment Cost Index, which measures total spending for wages and benefits, rose by a mild 0.9 percent in the second quarter, suggesting that the upturn in the economy proceeded without much pressure on corporate profits from rising labor costs. And the National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago index jumped in July, to 55.9 from 52.5 in June. The executives surveyed said that new orders for their merchandise were particularly strong.
A sleeper in the G.D.P. report may explain the apparent rise in orders. Companies, most of them retailers, drew down $17.9 billion in inventories of unsold merchandise in the second quarter. Many economists expect this to be followed by an increase in orders and production to replenish shelves. Even a small inventory swing, from the decline in the second quarter to, say, no change in the third quarter, could contribute nearly three-quarters of a percentage point to annual economic growth.
"The potential for big growth numbers in the last half of the year comes from the fact that inventories have been down and the trade deficit also has hurt the economy," Mr. Paulsen said, referring to a rise in imports, or production abroad, to satisfy consumer spending. "What if we get a quarter in which inventories rise and the trade deficit goes down. Suddenly, you can get into numbers like 5 percent G.D.P. growth."
That would get the economy through the short term, until the end of the year. Over the long term, much of the hope for a sustained recovery rests on a revival of business investment in equipment and software, which sank steadily for nearly two years, bringing on the recession in 2001, and forcing the economy into a weak recovery. A year ago, however, business investment began to show signs of life, and the latest gain, 7.5 percent, was the strongest quarterly performance in three years.
Most of the investment was to replace aging computers and software, but some was probably for expansion, the Bureau of Economic Analysis reported. That heartens James Glassman, senior domestic economist at J. P. Morgan Chase. He stirs together rising investment, rising business confidence and falling interest rates for corporate borrowing and sees in the mix sustained growth.
"Somewhere in the country there will be more hiring," Mr. Glassman said, "and that creates more income and more spending, and then we are on a virtuous cycle to recovery."

HEADLINE: State of Decline 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
From smog to silicon, from the sexual revolution to the tax revolt, the future has usually arrived in California first. Now the Golden State is degenerating into a banana republic. Can the nation be far behind?
 The recall isn't just a case of hardball politics. It's also a grand act of evasion: in the face of a severe fiscal crisis, voters are being invited to focus not on hard choices but on personality. Replacing Gray Davis with someone more likable isn't going to pay the bills. 
 And California's slide into irresponsibility, in which politicians refuse to acknowledge any connection between the government services the public demands and the taxes that pay for those services, is being replicated all across America.
Thanks to the end of the tech boom and the bursting of the tech bubble -- with an assist from energy price gouging -- California's budget has plunged into deficit. State and local governments faced with deficits normally respond with a mix of spending cuts and tax increases. That's what Mayor Michael Bloomberg has done in New York, it's what Gov. Pete Wilson did in California's last fiscal crisis, in the early 1990's, and it's what Mr. Davis proposed earlier this year.
But California's Constitution requires that budgets be passed in the State Legislature by a two-thirds' margin -- which gives the Republican minority blocking power. And that minority has refused either to vote for any tax increase, or to make realistic proposals for spending cuts.
You often hear claims that excessive spending is responsible for California's budget woes. True, budgets grew rapidly after the mid-1990's. But California began the 1990's by slashing outlays in response to a fiscal crisis, and most of the subsequent growth was simply a return to pre-crisis levels. As analysts at the nonpartisan California Budget Project point out, real state spending per capita was only 10 percent higher in 2002-03 than it was in 1989-90 -- that is, most of the spending growth was simply a matter of keeping up with the population and inflation.
The key factor in rising California spending has been the effort to rebuild a crippled education system. 
Proposition 13, the 1978 cap on property taxes, led to a progressive starvation of California's once-lauded public schools. By 1994, the state had the largest class sizes in the nation; its reading scores were on a par with Mississippi's. 
Voters wanted this shameful situation remedied. Indeed, much of the recent growth of education spending was mandated bya rather complex measure called Proposition 98. So when conservatives denounce "runaway government spending" in California, what they're really talking about is the effort to hire more teachers and repair decrepit school buildings.
Still, now the state faces a huge deficit, and spending must be cut. But shouldn't the state also seek more revenue? During California's last crisis, Governor Wilson increased the sales tax and temporarily raised income taxes on top brackets. This time Governor Davis proposed doing more or less the same thing -- but Senate Republicans refused to go along. Their counterproposal relied entirely on spending cuts -- but, tellingly, offered no specifics about what, exactly, should be cut. 
This week the stalemate was finally resolved, sort of. The budget that was passed contains one significant tax increase, a rise in the vehicle licensing fee -- for technical reasons, this didn't require a vote. And it uses elaborate fiscal footwork to evade restrictions on state borrowing, passing the problem on until next year. It's better than no budget at all, but it's a monument to political irresponsibility.
Which brings me to the final point: is Washington any better than Sacramento?
Outside the Social Security system, the federal government is now running a deficit equal to a third of its spending -- worse than California. The administration says it will never, ever contemplate increasing taxes; it says it will narrow the deficit through spending restraint, but has never said what spending it intends to restrain. 
If the federal government isn't in crisis, that's only because -- unlike state governments -- it isn't obliged to balance its budget each year. And so far bond markets have been willing to give the feds the benefit of the doubt.
But the people now running the country are every bit as irresponsible as those blocking a serious response to California's crisis. And sooner or later that irresponsibility will have the usual consequences. California, here we come.

PERSON: James F. Lima 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Governors Island Is His Oyster Now

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
HE is no Robert Moses. 
 Although he smiles puckishly about his new job like a toddler who has been given a giant Lego set, James F. Lima does not think of Governors Island as a field for his dreams, one in which he can erect monoliths and bulldoze whoever or whatever stands in his way. 
 Mr. Lima, who was chosen last month by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to be president of the Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation, the agency overseeing the island's redevelopment, sees his role as building a consensus -- a word not usually considered part of the imperious Moses' everyday vocabulary. 
"I have a lot of ideas for Governors Island, and I'm incredibly excited about exploring some of these ideas," Mr. Lima said in a recent interview. "But ultimately I will have been successful if I help all the people who have vested interests realize a shared vision that will take advantage of what is an extraordinary place."
Mr. Lima, a polished and measured man of 39, talked about his ideas in his quietly disarming style as he showed a reporter around the 172-acre former Army and Coast Guard base. He even managed to answer calls about the co-op he and his partner are trying to buy in Brooklyn Heights. (Memo to seller: watch out. This guy led the negotiations with the federal government that transferred the island to the city and state for $1, a better deal than Dutch settlers got when they bought it from Indians in 1637 for two ax heads, a string of beads and a handful of iron nails.)
Mr. Lima, a housing and development mandarin, would like to have plays and concerts in Castle Williams, an early-19th-century fort and prison whose curved sandstone walls are eight feet thick. He thinks low-slung Georgian brick buildings set around lawns on the island would be ideal for a college campus. He imagines athletics on the island's seven ball fields, and in its two pools. He thinks a demure hotel and conference center -- one that may take advantage of the island's nine-hole golf course -- would be a good idea for raising the $20 million a year needed to preserve the island's 60 vintage but decaying buildings.
Only the rebuilding of ground zero has the scale to overshadow the development of Governors Island, just 800 yards off Wall Street yet lushly shaded and tranquil with wraparound views of the harbor and skyline. Gambling and housing interests -- and, more recently, the City University -- have had their eyes on the island. The agreement with the federal government bars large-scale commercial and housing development.
Mr. Lima said he wanted to hear from "all corners of the city," both power brokers and those who may be plain broke, before putting forth any master plan. "If you're a kid in an overcrowded tenement in Chinatown, you could come here and learn about marine estuaries," he said. "This should be a resource, not just for tourists but for all parts of the city."
His Clark Kent style seems to have served him well where he has worked: the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the City Council's land-use subcommittee's staff, Forest City Ratner Companies (the developers), and most recently the city's Economic Development Corporation (where he is a senior vice president of the special projects division). 
He has had to navigate local politics and clashing business interests in redeveloping parts of the Rockaways, East New York, central and east Harlem, downtown Flushing and Downtown Brooklyn. In the latter project and the Governors Island transfer, he worked closely with Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, which helps account for his choice as the island's master builder. (His selection must be approved by the island's 12-member preservation board.)
MR. LIMA is the youngest of five children. His father, Henry, grew up on a farm in Rhode Island but became a restoration contractor, taking on some of the mansions around Newport. James Lima worked four summers for his father (who divorced his mother, Patricia, when he was 10). One restoration job was the occasion for one of the big adventures of his life -- getting stuck in a historic island lighthouse with five other workers during a hurricane. "We were stranded on this little island," he said, "six guys watching the waves come in ready to sweep us all away."
He majored in architecture at Columbia University but did his graduate studies, also at Columbia, in real estate development. "I think I decided I like having greater control over the whole range of project decision-making -- finance, zoning, infrastructure," he said. "I enjoy all the complexities." While an undergraduate, his roommate was Paul LaMedica, now a 42-year-old mortgage broker, and the two have been together ever since.
In his first job at the housing department, he also got a taste of how master-builder dreams can run into the shoals of economic downturns and other factors. He was assigned to come up with a plan for rebuilding the 300-acre Arverne neighborhood in the Rockaways, once a retreat of seaside bungalows that the city tore down in the 1960's. Mr. Lima is proud of the plan that he and community leaders and builders prepared in 1990. But the first 32 two-family houses in what is to be a 2,300-home community are still being built and will not go on sale until September. 
Mr. Lima, in other words, could have a long time to tinker with his new toy.

HEADLINE: Trade Center Arguments Fade, And a Single Vision Is Emerging 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
After months of arguing over Daniel Libeskind's winning design for the World Trade Center site, officials overseeing the rebuilding said yesterday that they had resolved most of their differences, and many agreed that the Libeskind plan was now likely to be built in substantially recognizable form.
 Three developments, in particular, appeared to reflect a growing consensus on how the colossal project should take shape. 
 Yesterday, for example, in announcing that a renowned Spanish architect, Santiago Calatrava, had been selected to design the site's new transportation terminal, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the 16-acre trade center site, essentially ruled out the idea of building an office tower atop the terminal. That ensures that its presence will rival the 1,776-foot tower and the memorial to victims of the Sept. 11 attack as signature elements of the redevelopment. 
Also yesterday, the Port Authority reached an agreement with the federal government that allows for the tower to be built on the northwest corner of the site, as Mr. Libeskind planned, rather than closer to the train station, as had been proposed by Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who holds the rights to office space at the site.
And the Bloomberg administration yesterday signaled its willingness to let the rebuilt trade center expand beyond its former boundaries, incorporating nearby parcels of privately owned land and allowing the disbursal of the 10 million square feet of office space into a less-crowded layout, as proposed by Mr. Libeskind.
Together, those developments put major rebuilding officials -- in the mayor's and governor's offices, the Port Authority and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation -- in agreement to a degree that has not occurred since the redevelopment project began.
"There's no question that everything is coming together," Charles A. Gargano, the vice chairman of the Port Authority, said yesterday. "I'm optimistic that things are now going to move forward very quickly."
City and state officials in particular have sparred over a number of issues recently, including the future of the development corporation and its $1.3 billion in remaining money for the rebuilding. 
"There's been a lot of talking about critical issues that are necessary to resolve before the more detailed planning work can get done," Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, said yesterday. 
"But we all feel under a significant amount of pressure to move this forward quickly," he added. "So we feel it's time to bring them to a close and move forward."
To be sure, some of the remaining details could become sticking points, and not all of the players may agree with the prescribed outcomes. While rebuilding officials say they have all but ruled out proposals by Mr. Silverstein to build an office tower over the train station and to move the 1,776-foot tower closer to the transportation hub, Mr. Silverstein's spokesman, Gerald McKelvey, said yesterday that he had not been told of those decisions and declined to comment further. 
But in the three months since Gov. George E. Pataki outlined a speedy timeline for the beginning of construction on the site's major projects, several issues appear to have won the approval of participants on all sides.
Mr. Libeskind, for example, had initially expressed a desire to be the lead architect on the train station, which several officials have referred to as a downtown Grand Central Terminal. But just as with the iconic tower, which will be designed by Mr. Silverstein's chosen architect, Mr. Libeskind will accept a secondary role. 
Because federal money will be used to build the station, the Federal Transit Administration required an architect with more experience on transportation projects. Now, Mr. Libeskind will set the "architectural design guidelines" for the terminal, while Mr. Calatrava will be the lead architect.
He will work as part of a team called the Downtown Design Partnership, a group that includes the engineering firms of DMJM+Harris and STV. Their work will include the design and engineering of the terminal and the underground concourses connecting the PATH commuter lines and the subway lines that run through or near the site. 
In a statement yesterday, Mr. Libeskind called Mr. Calatrava's work outstanding, adding, "Today is a great day in the rebirth of Lower Manhattan." 
Mr. Calatrava's office in Zurich is closed until mid-August, and his spokeswoman in the United States said he was traveling and could not be reached for comment.
The selection of Mr. Calatrava pleasantly surprised many of the civic and architecture groups that have closely followed the rebuilding effort. Mr. Calatrava is known primarily for his designs of railway stations and bridges throughout Europe. He has also designed the roof of the Athens Olympic Stadium for the 2004 Games and an addition to the Milwaukee Art Museum. 
"He's the poet of the train station," said Fredric Bell, the executive director of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
"His designs capture the spirit of movement," he added. "They are not static. Everything is moving and dynamic. I think he will be a true complement to the Libeskind plan."
Because both Mr. Libeskind and Mr. Calatrava are known for their strong personalities, it is unlikely that they will agree on everything. 
But Terence Riley, chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, said, "The chances for success are more than reasonable as long as it is very clear what each architect is responsible for."
Other important agreements regarding the trade center also appear to have emerged recently. The Port Authority has been studying where to place the security screening areas to be used by trucks making deliveries to buildings on the trade center site. 
Rather than restore them directly beneath the site, the agency's engineers have pushed to place them beneath two sites immediately south of Liberty Street that are currently occupied by the Deutsche Bank building, which will be torn down, and a parking lot. 
Those sites are being considered for some of the office space that would be moved off of the trade center property. Mr. Doctoroff said yesterday that he agreed that the areas beneath those sites could be better for truck screening.
The Port Authority also has agreed with federal officials that the United States Customs House, which formerly occupied the northwest corner of the site, will be moved to another portion of the site, freeing that corner for Mr. Libeskind's 1,776-foot tower.
Kevin Rampe, the president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said details remain to be worked out. 
"I don't want to be Pollyannaish," he said. "But all of the critical issues where there's been disagreement have either been decided or are nearing resolution."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Digital (Fill in the Blank) Is on the Horizon

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Nancy Savoy does not share the rapture of her technophile husband, Tom, when he starts talking about hardware and software, kilobits and megabytes.
 "My eyes glaze over," she said. "I'm not nerdy." 
 But Ms. Savoy, whose life is already surrounded by many of the amenities of modern technology -- a personal computer, high-speed Internet access, a cellphone, a digital camera and a DVD player -- did not hesitate when she was approached recently about joining a pilot program for digital home technology. 
Hers will be one of 20 families in the Boston area that will soon try out networked appliances, including next-generation ovens, which can both cook and refrigerate food and can be controlled remotely by using cellphones or personal computers.
"This is one of the answers to every busy mom's needs," said Ms. Savoy, a part-time tutor who has three daughters, ages 11, 13 and 20. "I'm eager to try it."
The technology world has been preoccupied in recent years by the boom-and-bust investment cycle -- the collapse of the dot-com bubble, the sharp fall in share prices on the Nasdaq stock market, and depressed spending by many large corporations. 
But there has been no such boom-and-bust cycle in the embrace of digital technology and its promise of benefits for communication, automation and new forms of art. And consumers, rather than paring back, are increasingly turning to all sorts of digital gadgets and services -- cameras, music players, videodisc players, advanced television sets, cellphones, instant messaging, e-mail, online shopping, high-speed Internet access.
"It's a step-by-step upward trend," said Nicholas Donatiello, president of Odyssey, a market research firm in San Francisco.
Since 1999, just before the technology boom collapsed, the percentage of households in the United States with personal computers -- which many experts thought was leveling off -- has in fact increased to 64 percent from 50 percent. At the same time, the share of households online has risen to 59 percent from 33 percent, and the use of digital cameras has climbed to 17 percent of households from less than 3 percent, according to Odyssey's research.
Some digital products are rapidly overtaking the conventional ones. Digital cameras are expected to outsell film-based cameras this year in the United States, the Photo Marketing Association International says. Just two years ago, more than twice as many film cameras were sold as digital cameras. And in the first six months of 2003, the value of DVD rentals at video stores outpaced VHS tape rentals for the first time, according to the Video Software Dealers Association.
The digital advance, to be sure, represents a challenge to many companies. The music industry's travail as people used their personal computers to copy MP3 music files and swap them over the Internet is a prime example. And a week ago, Eastman Kodak announced that it would cut as many as 6,000 workers from the payroll as its film sales fell, largely as a result of the growing popularity of digital cameras.
Beyond commerce, the influence of digital technology is being felt more and more in science, the arts and education. A report this year by a panel of the National Science Foundation, "Revolutionizing Science and Engineering Through Cyberinfrastructure," found "a new age has dawned in scientific and engineering research, pushed by continuing progress in computing, information and communication technology."
Digital technology is so malleable a tool because it renders everything -- words, numbers, music and images -- in bits, or binary digits, the 1's and 0's that are the computer's vernacular. The bits can be copied, transported, assembled and manipulated, using increasingly powerful computers and clever software, in limitless ways.
One field, among many, that has benefited from steady advances in computer simulation and analysis is research into the structure and workings of the human brain. 
"There has been an explosion in the use and impact of computation in recent years," said Dr. David Van Essen, a professor of neurobiology at Washington University in St. Louis. "And in many ways, it is still very early days in the use of digital tools in neuroscience."
Hollywood, too, is pushing the limits of digital technology. The special effects in most movies are increasingly dependent on computing, as are the most successful animated films, like this year's "Finding Nemo" from Pixar Animation Studios.
The cultural impact of the technology extends well beyond films, into art and music. "All the creative arts have become digital," said Michael Century, chairman of the arts department at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. "That is forcing us to rethink what it means to train people in the arts. The goal is to nurture integrated, multimedia creative minds."
Spending on information technology over all, most of it by corporations, is down about 5 percent worldwide since its peak in 2000, according to the International Data Corporation. Still, the level of spending -- at $867 billion last year -- remains high, more than twice that a decade ago.
Even big companies that are curtailing their spending say they remain confident in the power of technology to help them reduce costs, improve service and gain a competitive edge. General Motors has trimmed its information technology budget in recent years to just under $3 billion annually, and its plans call for further cuts next year. But G.M. is investing steadily in software and computer systems to increase its use of the Internet to communicate more closely with suppliers, dealers, industry partners and customers.
"Despite a difficult economy, that Web-based work to expand our external connections continues unabated," said Anthony E. Scott, the chief of technology for information services at G.M.
So while the disappointment of investors in technology stocks understandably gained a lot of attention, this market reaction tended to obscure a fundamental truth: the use and absorption of technology in society has not gone hand-in-hand with the psychology of investors. 
For consumers, the next big migration of digital technology is beyond the personal computer to music players, cameras and television sets. Among computer makers, Apple is an early leader in fashioning its Macintosh computers as "digital hubs" for the home and developing add-on devices like its popular iPod music player.
Other computer makers are pursuing similar strategies. Gateway, which has struggled to compete in the PC business, is in the midst of a sweeping transformation, said Ted Waitt, the chairman and chief executive. It is overhauling its product line to offer digital television sets and DVD players, which can be linked to personal computers. Later this year, the company plans to offer Gateway music players and digital cameras. "We want to be a branded integrator of home digital products, and not viewed as only a PC company," Mr. Waitt said.
Hewlett-Packard, the industry leader in computer printing, recognized years ago that digital cameras were closely related to its printing technology for capturing and rendering images. It introduced its first digital camera in 1998. "In essence, a digital camera is a computer with a lens," noted Chris Morgan, a Hewlett vice president. "And in our PC products, you'll see more focus on digital imaging."
In the last couple of years, the digital camera has become a mainstream product thanks to improvement in computer chips and storage, with performance typically doubling every 18 months. So digital pictures have become sharper, camera prices lower and besides, the images can be e-mailed or printed, all without film.
Because digital technology is so flexible -- programmable, in computing terms -- digital products, if not wisely designed, can be maddeningly confusing to use. Some digital cameras have that kind of flaw, and the common complaint of frustrated users is telling: "This isn't a camera, it's a computer."
Such issues of design and usability are magnified in home technology experiments, as in the high-tech kitchen pilot project in suburban Boston. If digital technology is really going to be brought into the home, it has to be domesticated -- engineered to work more like an appliance and less like a general-purpose computer.
"This technology has to be integrated and simplified for the average consumer," said Tim Woods, vice president of the Internet Home Alliance, a corporate group sponsoring the kitchen project. "Teenagers and techies will put up with plenty of aggravation to get technology to work. Mom will not. Her life is too complicated."
The project, called Mealtime, will run for about four months, beginning the middle of this month. The companies supplying equipment and technology include Whirlpool, Icebox, I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard and Sears, Roebuck. Besides the networked oven that can also chill food, each household will have a refrigerator linked to the Internet for automated reordering of groceries through Peapod, the online grocer.
"We're trying to bridge the world of the Internet with the world of white goods," said Bill Bodin, director of an I.B.M. advanced technology laboratory.
The companies involved all recognize they are taking part in an experiment that may well be ahead of its time. "We fully realize that this is something that could take years to really take off," said Tim Langan, director of emerging home solutions at Sears. "But we have to understand this technology, and how people may use it, if we're going to be relevant."
And for all her aversion to technobabble, Ms. Savoy -- whose long days are filled with her tutoring work and household chores, and shuttling her 11- and 13-year-old daughters to soccer, ice hockey, tennis and music lessons -- remains enthusiastic.
"I see it as a way to plan ahead and simplify my life," Ms. Savoy said. "And I'm always willing to try new things."

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
State Still Oversees City's Budget Plan Despite Albany's Own Fiscal Woes

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
As the governor and the State Financial Control Board approved the city's budget plan yesterday, the event was laced with historical paradox.
 The state, in essence, gave its stamp of approval to the city's plan to balance its current budget without going into debt even as the state's own spending plan hinges on $4.2 billion in borrowing for current expenses, a trick state law prohibits the city from using. 
 It was the equivalent of a parent telling a child to do as I say rather than as I do, several budget watchdogs said.
When the Financial Control Board was formed in 1975, the roles were reversed. The city was deeply in debt and borrowing money on a monthly basis just to meet its payroll, and the state was, by comparison, a flush and well-run operation. 
Today, after nearly 30 years under the strict fiscal rules the state imposed on the city, the city has some of the most transparent and cautious budgeting practices in the country. By law, four agencies monitor the city's finances, and if the city fails to balance its budget or pay its debt, the state takes over the city's finances.
The state government, meanwhile, has become addicted to fiscal gimmicks, one-time revenues, off-budget authorities and, this year, a questionable borrowing mechanism to deal with its financial crisis, fiscal experts said. And there is no fiscal watchdog on the state level to object, beyond bond raters.
"It's ironic that the state holds the city to much higher standards than it holds itself," said Marcia Van Wagner, the chief economist at the Citizens Budget Commission.
Indeed, one of the main risks for the city's finances next year is the precarious state of the state's finances. Because Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders relied heavily on borrowing and other one-time revenues, the gap lawmakers have to close in the state budget will be at least $5.3 billion. The governor and the Legislature may well be forced to drastically reduce aid to the city to make ends meet.
"The state's budget is still in deep trouble," said State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, a Democrat.
Mr. Hevesi, like other members of the Financial Control Board, praised Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday for steering the city through the recent crisis. He said the mayor and the City Council have reduced spending by about $3 billion this year and raised taxes by $2.7 billion, bitter medicine that has driven his popularity down, according to polls, but has left the city in relatively sound financial shape going into next year. 
The comptroller said the state, however, had merely put off much of its budget woes until next year, borrowing $4.2 billion in bonds backed by the state's general fund and money it receives from tobacco companies as part of a court settlement. The bonds will be used for paying salaries and other recurring expenses, a cardinal sin in budget-making. "The state has depended on one-shots and borrowing to such an excessive degree that it means you haven't solved the problem," Mr. Hevesi said. "You have just postponed it."
Governor Pataki first proposed the idea of borrowing to help close the state's $12 billion gap when he presented his budget in January. In May, the Legislature passed tax increases to pay for some spending the governor had cut, but left the borrowing in the plan, though it adjusted the collateral. The governor vetoed large parts of the budget, and the Legislature promptly overrode his vetoes. The borrowing remained, however, and at least one bond rating agency downgraded city bonds. 
Asked yesterday about the state's borrowing and the double standard for the city, Mr. Pataki said, "I'm proud of the fiscal policies we have had at the state level since I have been governor." He also added that "the budget that was adopted over my objections this year does not reflect my fiscal policies," even though the bonds had been his proposal.
Spokesmen for the legislative leaders, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, pointed out that, had the state not borrowed money, the city would have received far less aid for schools and other programs. All told, the Legislature restored about $1 billion in aid for the city that the governor had cut or not included in his budget.
"Were it not for the actions the State Legislature took and the budget we adopted, the city would be in a lot worse shape," John McArdle, a spokesman for Senator Bruno, said.
State budget officials say Mr. Pataki's original plan was to use the borrowed $4.2 billion to ease the pain of reducing the size of government over two years, but the Legislature opted to use it all this year.
They also point out that the city's debt burden as a percentage of its budget is still about three times the state's, because of the huge borrowing former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani approved. Finally, they contend that the gap the city faces next year, $2.8 billion, is about the same size in proportion to the city's $43.6 billion budget as the $5.3 billion gap is to the state's $92.8 billion budget.
Yet fiscal monitors say the city's willingness to shrink the work force by 9,000 over the last two years and cut services while simultaneously raising taxes means the Bloomberg administration is on the road to a balanced budget. The state, meanwhile, has merely put off many tough decisions, monitors said. That is largely because lawmakers used the tax increases they enacted to avoid deep cuts to education aid and medical services, rather than to replace the governor's proposed borrowing.
"It's just borrowing on top of borrowing," Mr. Hevesi said yesterday, "and borrowing is just putting off the problem."

HEADLINE: Filling a Creative Void at Ground Zero 

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
The site plan represents the destruction of Sept. 11. Now the architecture will provide the creative response. That's the implicit message in the selection of Santiago Calatrava to design a permanent replacement for the PATH station that was destroyed by the attack on the World Trade Center in 2001. At last, the controversial plan developed by Daniel Libeskind for the site begins to make sense. From it, great things might grow.
 Mr. Calatrava, 52, is the world's greatest living poet of transportation architecture. A native of Spain, Mr. Calatrava trained as both an engineer and an architect. He is best known as a designer of bridges, train stations and airports, masterworks of our time. Long before the word "infrastructure" had entered the lexicon of contemporary architecture, Mr. Calatrava had taken this genre of design to the level of genius. 
 Though his main office is in Zurich, in recent years Mr. Calatrava has been living part time in New York. His first American project, a time capsule designed for The New York Times, is displayed at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. The Milwaukee Art Museum addition, his first major public building in this country, opened last year to critical acclaim. Mr. Calatrava is also well known in New York as the architect of a project as yet unrealized: a new transept and spire for the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights.
Admirers have long detected a spiritual dimension in Mr. Calatrava's secular work, particularly in Spain. The Communications Tower and City of Science complex, designed for Valencia, has the tripartite arrangement of a Gothic cathedral. The Montjuic Communications Tower in Barcelona gestures skyward like a waving hand, as if to consecrate the air through which electronic messages pass. Inevitably, with its taut cables suspended from a single inclined pylon overhead, the Alamillo Bridge in Seville sparks images of celestial harps.
Some structural engineers have criticized Mr. Calatrava for including expressive forms not strictly required by functional needs. That is like attacking an apple for not being an orange. Twentieth-century functionalism is only one of the cultural strains on which Mr. Calatrava has drawn. His sources also include geometry, human anatomy, animal skeletons and other natural forms. Kinesthetics, the perception of movement, is also central to his work. It harks back to a time when expressive form in architecture stood for exuberance and generosity, not a failure to economize.
The choice of Mr. Calatrava is the clearest sign yet that the rebuilding of ground zero will be an achievement of cosmopolitan dimensions. The city has come far from the time, just more than a year ago, when it had entrusted the design process to a local group of insiders bereft of a vision adequate to the historical challenge before them.
It is doubly amazing that this sign of serious intent should be issued by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, an agency whose architectural standards in recent years have slipped comfortably downhill.
Some New Yorkers who have been following recent developments at ground zero may find themselves secretly hoping that there will be fireworks between Mr. Calatrava and Mr. Libeskind. They may get their wish. In the past several months, Mr. Libeskind seems to have forgotten that he was retained not to design buildings, but to assist the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation in preparing a master plan forthe 16-acre site.
The corporation appears to have forgotten this, too. It seems that the louder Mr. Libeskind has voiced his demands, the more control he has been awarded over the design of buildings planned for the site. And the state agency has yet to produce an actual master plan.
In his presentation to the agency last December, Mr. Libeskind called for "great architects" to help realize his vision. A client would not, in any case, hire a designer of Mr. Calatrava's stature simply to execute the ideas of an architect who has given some New Yorkers cause to fear that he may have difficulty distinguishing sunlight from shade.
With architects of the quality of Mr. Calatrava, many New Yorkers will find it easier to appreciate the value of Mr. Libeskind's original inclusive approach. A stylized re-creation of the shock waves felt around the world on 9/11, the Libeskind plan has aroused opposition on the grounds that it would inflict a perpetually open wound on Lower Manhattan. The wound would serve a constructive purpose, however, if it were surrounded by unmistakable signs of the city's resilience.
Memory Foundations: that is the name of the proposal Mr. Libeskind submitted last year, and it is a good one. There is much to be remembered on this site, much life along with death. And we must learn to see this project literally as a re-membering, a putting together of pieces that have been violently torn apart.
