HEADLINE: Cons In Class 

BYLINE:  By Abby Ellin; Abby Ellin writes a column about young people for the Money & Business section of The Times.

DATELINE: Ossining, N.Y. 

 BODY:
IGNORE the razor wire twisted outside the windows, and the school building at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility feels like most other academic institutions. Classrooms are filled with blackboards, freestanding globes, desk-and-chair combinations. Inspirational messages line the walls: If you don't get it, try again! Some people have to learn the hard way! Never settle for less than your best! But here, 30 miles up the Hudson from New York City, students don't linger after class. They are herded back to their cells the minute the clock hits 8:30. 
 On this night, Rosemarie Murray's "Written English and Literary Studies I" class is discussing the plays read over the semester: "Oedipus," "Hamlet," "Othello" and "A Doll's House." Last week they had been asked to answer essay questions, and Dr. Murray hands back their responses. 
 "Some people thought they were writing sentences and I was forced to write 'sentence fragment,"' she says. "You all know what I mean, right?" The men nod. 
Next week's assignment: to write a paper on "marriage through the mirror of drama." The men, most in their 20's and 30's, look at her blankly. She tries again. "What do the plays we've read so far tell us about marriage?" she says. "How about 'A Doll's House'?"
The men raise their hands. It's life, one says. "Woman kills husband, husband kills wife -- everyday life."
"Marriages explode because of economic problems," says another.
"Men and women go into marriage for different reasons," says a third.
"So the relationship between the sexes has not changed very much," Dr. Murray proffers. The conversation strikes a chord, and the men start talking about their own lives. This happens a lot, she says. "The tenor of the class, the openness, those are constants. Once we were talking about the opinions the world has of you versus your own identity. The labels 'black men,' 'prisoner' -- what does this mean to your own sense of self? Literature is about how conflict changes people. Here are real-life people dealing with real-life conflicts."
Educating prisoners is something Dr. Murray believes in strongly. "I've always had sympathies for people who make the wrong choices," she says. A former dean of students at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., she wrote her graduate school dissertation on prison education and recidivism rates. She rarely asks her students what crime they committed, and she has never felt unsafe. "It's a maturity thing," she says. "Nobody's 18. They've been in long enough and they understand that education is the key. Part of their motivation is because most of them are getting out."
She continues: "One of the best responses I've heard for why men and women in prisons should study philosophy was: 'For the same reason people do it at Harvard.' No matter where you are, it's the same. Like what happened to Malcolm X -- he copied the dictionary, he loved words. There's power in being an educated man who can use words."
Inmate number 86A348, Juan Roldan, also loves words. But he didn't know that until he went to prison and started studying. 
Mr. Roldan, 40, has spent 17 years behind bars and has almost eight more to go before he's eligible for parole. His sentence is big -- 25 to life for robbing and murdering a cabdriver in the Bronx. At 6 feet 2 and 230 pounds, Mr. Roldan looks as if he spends a lot of time working out, and he does. The rest of the day he sweeps and mops, for which he gets $5 every two weeks, or studies. He rarely watches television. 
Mr. Roldan grew up on the Lower East Side long before it was fashionable, and then moved in with his father in Camden, N.J. After graduating from high school he considered joining the Marines but stayed behind for a girl. He took menial jobs, ran with a rough crowd and got into drugs. He won't give specifics about his crime. He was locked up at the Greenhaven Correctional Facility, a maximum-security prison in Stormville, N.Y., for 14 years. There, he participated in a range of therapeutic programs. One day, in transactional analysis, the teacher asked him to make a list of all the pros and cons in his life. 
Here were the pros: He had had money, two cars and an apartment in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He had a high school diploma. He was assertive, intelligent, strong. Then the cons: "I'm in prison. I used drugs. I've got no car, no wife, no apartment. The only thing left was the high school diploma. Reality smacked me in the face. I cried, 'I ruined my life.' The cons got bigger: I'm overly assertive, overly aggressive. I need to be humble. I'm in prison. That's when I decided to do my best here."
He began by taking classes. Greenhaven offered a degree program through Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., but, after Mr. Roldan had earned 84 credits, President Bill Clinton signed legislation in 1994 making convicted felons ineligible for Pell grants, the federal tuition assistance program for low-income students. At the time, nearly 27,000 inmates were paying for college with the grants, costing the government $35 million annually. Most states, including New York, withdrew financial aid for prison education, and more than 350 programs shut down nationwide. 
Mr. Roldan was devastated. But four years later he got wind of Sing Sing's privately financed program and applied for a transfer. His request was granted and Mercy College, the degree-granting institution, accepted his credits. After this semester, he needs three more courses to graduate; eventually, he says, he wants to be a medical doctor. 
The walls of his 9-by-5-foot cell, which he says affords a teasing view of the Hudson, are plastered with photographs of the ocean, the solar system, K-2. A typewriter, lamp and desk sit on one side. Stacks of books are piled against a wall. He says he knows all about the history of Americans, Jews, Africans, American Indians and the Celts. He's read Plato, Socrates, Greek and Roman mythology. ("Well, they got that from the Greek," he says.) He studies math, his worst subject, daily. 
His passion is English. His favorite is Rudyard Kipling's "If." "That speaks to me," he says, along with Keats and "the woman writer -- Anne Sexton.
"I love her because she writes like me, the emotion of it, the despair. She was in a mental institution and she said her writing was from the depths of her being. Like when Jimi Hendrix was playing his guitar and it unplugged and he kept on playing. Sometimes I feel like prison chokes me, which it's designed to do. I find solace in reading and learning. This experience needs to be more than an individual, Juan Roldan, 86A348, doing 25 years. When I leave prison I want to leave with a college degree, a master's and a Ph.D. -- not covered in tattoos or pierced."
Sentiment against higher education in prison has grown even more acute as states squeeze the budgets of public universities, with officials and the public challenging whether the humanities is appropriate to prepare prisoners for the outside -- and what of those who may never be released, like Juan Roldan?
State Senator Michael F. Nozzolio, a Republican from Seneca Falls, who heads the Crime and Corrections Committee, supports vocational training and test preparation for general education diplomas and is seeking to make them mandatory as a condition of parole. But he says that higher education is unfair "when law-abiding, taxpaying citizens are stretched to the limit trying to pay their college tuitions." 
"Certainly," he says, "if an inmate wishes to pursue a college education or correspondence courses we'll encourage that, but in my district I saw inmates that have no chance of ever getting out of prison becoming philosopher kings at taxpayer expense."
After the Pell grants were ended, the Youthful Offenders Program was created to provide federal funds for postsecondary education to inmates under age 26, but only those eligible for parole or release within five years. States have the latitude to emphasize vocational or academic education; most blend the two. The program, which went into effect in 1998, is considered a positive step, though the Correctional Educational Association, an organization of prison educators, is lobbying to raise the age ceiling to 35.
"There is good support for postsecondary education that has a vocational basis to it, and that means more jobs," says Stephen J. Steurer, executive director of the association. "When we had Pell grants people were getting A.A. degrees and B.A. degrees, but you got this whole public 'I work to put my kids through college and these bums are getting free help.' I understand it. I also understand the other viewpoint about public safety and reduction of crime."
Study after study has shown that education improves the chances that inmates will not return to prison. A 2001 study sponsored by the federal Department of Education reported a 20 percent drop in recidivism rates among more than 3,000 inmates in Maryland, Minnesota and Ohio who had participated in an academic or vocational program. Another study, by the Bureau of Justice Statistics, found that 65 percent of those with some high school went back to jail, compared with 57 percent of high school graduates and 52 percent of those with some college.
"It's the college experience -- and particularly graduation or completion of any diploma, some sense of walking down the aisle and completion -- that significantly decreases recidivism rates," says Michelle Fine, a professor of psychology at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. "The evidence is strong for any educational intervention. Our analyses, however, suggest that with a liberal arts degree students gain the skills that are necessary for work situations -- persistence, social analysis and surviving on the outside, the skills of 'reading' the social situation, knowing how to overcome in the face of daunting obstacles, and how to consider alternatives."
Dr. Fine is an author of a study in 2001 that tracked about 2,300 women for three years after their release from the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility in Westchester County, which re-established a program in 1997 through a consortium of private New York colleges and universities and with donors like Glenn Close and Paul Newman. Nearly 30 percent of those who hadn't taken classes wound up back in jail, compared with 8 percent of those who had. Dr. Fine says each inmate who returns to prison costs $25,000 a year. "Incarceration of 100 prisoners for four years costs the state $10 million; college in prison for four years costs the state $1 million but recidivism rates drop dramatically, yielding a cost savings of hundreds of millions of dollars." 
Ultimately, it is up to each state to determine whether it will offer a college education. Last year, before Gov. George H. Ryan of Illinois left office, he decided not to abandon in-prison college to help balance the state budget; 23 of its 27 prisons have a program with area community colleges, which absorb some of the expense. In Texas, nearly 10,000 inmates take college-level courses financed by private scholarships and the Youthful Offenders Program. Inmates over 26 pay full tuition either up front or as a condition of parole. About 600 inmates are studying for a degree in Maryland, with the first graduating class in May; in addition, with a $1 million grant from the Department of Education, the state has developed an online curriculum. "It's a national demonstration project to prove we can deliver online courses safely to incarcerated adults," says D. Ray Harbert, coordinator of postsecondary programs for Maryland's education department. 
Only five of New York State's 70 prisons have degree-granting programs, all privately financed. Sing Sing's program was created, at the behest of inmates, by Anne Reissner, a volunteer at the prison who founded the nonprofit Hudson Link for Higher Education. The first classes were held in 2000 and taught by Nyack College. 
A year later, with Nyack facing financial problems, Mercy College took over. Sixty-five prisoners are now enrolled, and degrees in behavioral science will be conferred on the first Mercy graduates next June. "Once they leave prison most get jobs working in human services, like drug counseling or with at-risk youth," Ms. Reissner says. Prisoners must apply just like any other student and contribute about 12 percent, or $30, of their annual earnings. They also get paid $5 every two weeks for attending (school is classified as a job). Mercy charges about $3,000 a class. 
OF course, just because you have a degree doesn't mean it's easy after prison. Inmates don't have to worry about health insurance or finding the next meal or paying rent or, for that matter, what time to wake up and go to sleep. Real-world pressures can overwhelm someone who has spent half his life locked up, as recidivism rates clearly indicate. Education helps.
Sean Pica, 34, was released from Sing Sing in mid-December, having been incarcerated at 17 for killing a classmate's father in Selden, N.Y. (The case was turned into a TV movie, "A Deadly Silence," which he has never seen.) Guards dropped him off at the train station at Ossining, handed him $40, and that was that. "They were very nice," he recalls. "They shook my hand when I left." 
"All you hear about is the recidivism rate, that 60 percent go back to prison. How can that be?" says Mr. Pica. "And then you experience it and you say, 'This system is designed for failure.' You have guys like me that have done years in jail and they say, 'All I want to do is go out. I'll make it work.' Then they get out and they don't have a car. Where are they going to go? They're all by themselves. What are they going to do?"
"Part of me wants to say we're doing fine with private funding, and this way we don't have to deal with people who say, 'Why should my tax money pay for your education?' But you wouldn't have wanted me to stay the way I was. I was a wild, mixed-up, crazy kid. And if I hadn't settled down and gotten educated -- I wasn't a neighbor you would want."
While in jail, Mr. Pica got his high school equivalency diploma, his bachelor's from Nyack College and, last year, his master's in professional studies in a program offered by the New York Theological Seminary. "When I went up there and got the degree I thought, 'This is the first time in my life I earned something,"' he recalls. "A lot of guys aren't career criminals; most are guys like me who got in trouble as kids."
Mr. Pica believes in luck. Shortly after his release he got a job busing tables and doing carpentry at a restaurant. "What's the chances of that happening?" he asks. "I could have picked a million other places and not gotten a response." He just started a job counseling at a nonprofit employment agency in Harlem, making $29,000 a year, and will begin a master's program at Hunter College in September. 
Juan Roldan may never be released. He's up for parole in 2010, but few succeed the first time. Mr. Roldan dreams about it often. A lot has changed in 17 years: Ronald Reagan, George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton have come and gone. A space shuttle blew up, and then another. A millennium flipped by. And two of the largest buildings in the world no longer stand. The Internet and cellphones have become indispensable parts of everyday life -- not that Mr. Roldan has actually used either. "My goal is to take my laptop, plug in my cellphone and touch someone in Denmark," he says. 
Right now, though, he's staying focused on doing the "right thing." That in itself is a victory. "I am a success story," he says. "I have not succumbed to the subculture of prison. Drugs, being a crook -- you can come to prison and do things that aren't positive."
And who knows? Maybe one day he will achieve his goal of being a doctor. "Ironic," he says, "that I'm here for murder."

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Education Life section on Aug. 3 about college courses in prison misstated the circumstances under which Nyack College, in New York State, suspended its program at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility. The decision reflected plans to shut the medium-security area; the Nyack program served primarily those prisoners. Financial problems were not the reason.

HEADLINE: ENDPAPER; 
A Reluctant Reunion

BYLINE:  By Leslie Kandell; Leslie Kandell, a freelance journalist specializing in the arts, is working on a book about church choirs.

 BODY:
ADDING what I've heard to what I'm sure of, I can now account for the whole front row of my class photo, and a couple of children in the middle and rear. By "my class," I mean one of the fifth grades in Public School 2 on the Lower East Side, where I taught when John F. Kennedy was president.
 I found that old photo after a friend transferred to a CD the decaying reel-to-reel tapes I had made when I lugged my newfangled recorder into the classroom just for fun. The CD, rising from the tapes' ashes, revealed a young teacher talking and singing with students and rehearsing "Lonesome Train," the folk oratorio that was our class play. Getting the children together again, to hear the CD and share memories, sounded like a great idea. With naive enthusiasm, I set out to round them up. 
 New York City schools don't track their graduates, although Caroline Kennedy, in her new role as fund-raiser for the city's Department of Education, says she hopes to form an alumni association of some kind. But for now, the one doing the homework is me. And after a series of dead ends, I'm thinking it's easier to find a witness in a protection program. Class records from before the computer era are unavailable. Colleagues are retired. Everyone I knew in the administration is dead. I don't find my kids on Classmates.com or through directory assistance. Private detectives want the moon -- Social Security numbers and girls' married names.
I wish my former students could reconnect -- with being 10, with what they once learned, with forgotten friends. During my search, someone suggests that I'm the one looking to recapture my youth. It's true: as I grow older, I become a nostalgia-seeker, a retriever of memories. Shared history makes time fall away. The bond forged by knowing someone early in life should endure. 
Perhaps I'm the one learning the lessons.
ONCE, long before P.S. 2 was built, the Lower East Side teemed with immigrants who arrived with nothing, sometimes not even their own names. Their children, among them the Irving Berlins, the Danny Kayes, the Al Jolsons, took advantage of free education and worked their way out of poverty, pointing with pride to the picturesque pushcarts and tenements of their beginnings.
But by the late 60's, the streets had an aura of incipient danger -- "West Side Story" with less charm and more drugs. It wasn't a neighborhood where boys fled the Vietnam draft by going to college or Canada. They left high school and went into the service. Not all came back.
I study the smiling boys in the class photo sitting cross-legged down front. (Notices were sent home, and the children who weren't going to doll up just didn't come that day.) Left to right: Chinese, Italian, Hispanic, Greek. In other rows more of each, and blacks, Poles, a Hawaiian -- the original Rainbow Coalition.
Eddie (front row, far left) joined a gang and Mike (far right) thinks Eddie is long dead (I certainly can't find him). A few are listed on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, and I find two other death certificate matches. (Someone thinks Gary P. is dead, too, but about 35 years ago he looked me up and visited along with his fiancee. He wanted me to know that after reform school and prison, he had a job paving sidewalks and was taking night courses in algebra so he could be a construction manager. So I believe he's out there somewhere.) Andrew (front row, red jacket) now lives in Minnesota. He had won a merit scholarship to Brown University from Seward Park, where most P.S. 2 graduates go but only 28 percent of entering freshmen graduate. (At Stuyvesant, within walking distance, it's 93 percent.) The number of Seward Park applicants admitted to Brown in the lastdecade is zero.
I call Andrew. "Maybe the best thing you did was show us what's out there," he tells me.
In my day at P.S. 2, teachers were busy scooping batches of students into the next grade and forgetting them, as they forgot us. So when Mike hears my name on the phone, he growls, "Get out of here" with inflections right out of "The Sopranos." He startles me back when I ask, "How old are you now, Mikey?" I am ready to hear 30, but he's 52. (Surely that's older than I am, isn't it?)
When I say I remember him as a perfect child, he shouts to his family, "Hey, the teacher says I was a perfect child!"
I ask Mike if he will get hold of classmates so we can get together. "No," he says, "I want to meet with you alone."
I would have put on a pleasant expression on the way up the subway steps, but Mike is too quick not to guess that, and evidently wishes to see my face when I recognize him. He is down on the platform watching for me. We are both dazed.
We sit in a downtown Greek diner, where he knows the owner, for three and a half hours, during which time we have one cup of coffee that we don't want. I remember Mike as someone I could rely on to get a job done, a stable child. "Nam" was devastating for him. What he saw there, and did, left him with post-traumatic stress disorder, documented in a government file as "permanently unemployable" because of "episodes of unprovoked violence." So he goes to the V.A. hospital and lives on disability he would give up in a heartbeat for a decent job.
I hear about heroin, armed robbery, prisons, diabetes, liver problems and dentures. He says, though, that when he was in prison, he asked for the job of librarian "because the morons and maniacs who can't read won't be in there." It turns out he writes a little, and what I see has none of the common grammatical errors that annoy me. "Wonder where I learned that," he says.
I'm beginning to grasp what courage it took to come out to that diner to meet me. I wonder if the sudden appearance of Teacher, assigning him to compare who he was to who he is, isn't a greater danger to him than he is to me. "We're us," Mike says. "You're them."
But in those direct eyes I see again the reliable co-captain of the P.S. 2 safety squad -- the other co-captain's name is on the Vietnam wall -- and across an abyss of time and class, we remember each other with love. I'm sure of that.
When I find Effie, now an artist, she has a very old bone to pick: "Do you remember when you took us on a trip to the Cloisters?" Sort of. "And you lost your watch?" Oops. "Well, you made us all look for it."
I regret spoiling her trip. I remember that the watch had been a gift from my father. I speak of my worry over the loss, and my fear of disappointing him. Mollified by an unexpected apology, she speaks of her own father's savage temper. She goes on to recall being the narrator in the class play, and mentions my interest in the cello, the first time she noticed that a teacher could have a life beyond school.
We finally meet. She has never had a reunion experience, and is suspicious at first. She listens to the tape, and we talk and talk. "You're not going to make me leave now, are you?" she says after the afternoon is gone. No I'm not. We figure out a few more names on the photo. Later, she makes a date to meet with Mikey.
This isn't turning out like any reunion I have ever gone to. It will be a long time before my fifth graders sit in the same room eating cookies, or whatever I was imagining, and listening to that tape. What I've found is less complete but no less compelling.
I persuade Mike to read his journal to his veterans' group. "It's hard, but not impossible," he tells me after he has tried it. "Just when I thought there was no more road, another half-mile showed up."
And as my search continues, connecting with each of them is like a half-mile showing up for me. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Class photo from Public School 2 on the Lower East Side. Getting together again sounded like a great idea, but these students were not to be found on Classmates.com.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Modigliani's Recipe: Sex, Drugs and Long, Long Necks

BYLINE:  By PETER PLAGENS; Peter Plagens is a painter and the art critic for Newsweek.

 BODY:
VINCENT VAN GOGH had a 10-year working life that can hardly be called a "career," and yet he's just about the biggest draw ever in museum exhibitions, at least per square inch of canvas covered. When the 1998 "Van Gogh's van Goghs" exhibition entered the home stretch of its run at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, officials had to keep the place open 24 hours a day on the last weekend to accommodate the crowds.
 O.K., that's van Gogh. But since June 26, visitors have been streaming into the same museum at the rate of more than 1,400 a day (which a spokesperson calls "astounding" for them) to see the work of a different painter with an equally brief working life. The attraction, which originated at the Albright-Knox Gallery in Buffalo (where the museum had to turn away visitors during the last two weeks) and then stopped at the Kimbell Museum in Fort Worth, is an exhibition called "Modigliani and the Artists of Montparnasse." (It runs through Sept. 28.) Although the show includes healthy doses of Chagall, Soutine and Rivera (among others), the benighted Amedeo Modigliani (1884-1920) is the real draw. 
 What is it about this artist, who painted deceptively simple, semi-abstracted, sloe-eyed women over and over again, that pleases the public so much? 
It could be at least partly the biography. Modigliani was born an outsider -- his parents were Sephardic Jews in Livorno, Italy -- and grew up sickly and tubercular. He arrived in Paris at 18, wide-eyed and ambitious, and quickly fell into a passionate, bohemian existence of drugs, alcohol and brothels. He really wanted to be a sculptor and daubed mostly because of poverty (the ultracheap medium of assemblage hadn't been invented yet). In addition to Chagall, Soutine and Rivera, his supporting cast of avant-garde arrivistes included Giorgio de Chirico, Juan Gris, Elie Nadelman, Piet Mondrian, Constanin Brancusi, Jacob Epstein, Sonia Delaunay and Jacques Lipchitz.
Oh, yes, and Picasso. 
Modigliani met Picasso in 1909 and was later haunted, enraged, awed and made envious by every artistic move this transplanted Spaniard made. But where the wily Picasso gradually cobbled together a kind of prosperity, Modigliani stayed dirt poor, frequently changing residences only one jump ahead of eviction and constantly trying to settle unpayable debts with drawings. He died Byronically, of meningitis, at 35. A day after his burial in Pere Lachaise cemetery, his distraught mistress, Jeanne Hebuterne -- the mother of his 14-month-old daughter and pregnant again -- committed suicide by defenestration. Modigliani's doomed life is the stuff of which movies are made. Sure enough, a feature film about him, with Andy Garcia in the title role, was announced in April.
But give the public some credit: the art on the wall must have something to do with it, and it does. Modigliani's painting -- although it probably seemed to the haute bourgeoisie of Paris in the teens as incomprehensible as anything produced by the overwrought Fauves and certifiably crazy Cubists -- was never really as far out as that of his peers, especially Picasso. Modigliani liked the attenuated, melancholic figures of Picasso's Blue Period, not the spiky, angry and downright threatening fragmented prostitutes of "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon," and his own painting shows it.
Modigliani also liked Brancusi's aerodynamically modern sculpture, which, if militantly abstract (or at least abstracted), is nothing if not harmonious in the economical extreme. Modigliani's painting shows that, too. We might say -- as some critics have -- that Modigliani looks a little bloodless next to the fevered, meaty angst of Soutine, but we can't deny the ingeniously soothing design (yes, design; it's not a dirty word) in Modigliani's paintings. The public lines up for sage introspection (Rembrandt) and the sunny, leafy outdoors (Monet), but it also likes finely balanced "S" curves. It's almost a kinesthetic thing; try it by drawing a figure 8. That graceful, graphic simplicity, together with his embracingly warm colors, lends Modigliani's painting what the Futurist artist Gino Severini called a "Tuscan elegance." 
Modigliani painted portraits and female nudes almost exclusively. Since most people like to look at images of people, and even straight women like to look at the cleavage on the covers of women's magazines like Cosmopolitan, Modigliani's paintings have a broad and deeply anchored appeal.
Sitters in Modigliani's portraits are invariably elongated, especially in the neck. From El Greco and Parmagianino through today's fashion illustration, elongation is preferred. The portraits' faces resemble masks in a comforting, Hello Kitty! sort of way (as opposed to a terrifying, Jason-from-the-"Halloween"-movies sort of way). Whatever inner turmoil -- or ennui -- the subject is suffering, Modigliani manages to bowdlerize it without entirely obliterating the sitter's engaging humanity. His 1916 portrait of his hyper-expressionist friend Soutine looks a lot like Keanu Reeves.
As for the nudes, they're the modernist version of the socially sanctioned cheesecake -- Cabanel's "Birth of Venus," for example -- that emanated from the late-19th-century French academy. (I can recall arty undergraduate friends pinning up Modigliani repros instead of Playboy centerfolds in their dorm rooms.) Modigliani also pushes the envelope a bit: the viewer looks down at a Modigliani nude, seeing her as if she's waiting for a hovering lover to come to bed, and his paintings were occasionally confiscated for exposing too much pubic hair. People who go to contemporary-art exhibitions in museums these days enjoy that quaint trace of transgressiveness.
If this sounds dismissive, it isn't. It's just a partial inventory of the buttons his work pushes. Were that the sum of Modigliani's painting, he'd be little better than one of those nightclub "elegant" poster artists like Patrick Nagel, whose works decorate hairdressing salons and white-shag-carpet condos from Coral Gables to La Jolla.
But Modigliani doesn't just delineate -- he paints, really paints. There's enough color and surface modulation, beautifully and subtly achieved through a short, staccato brush stroke (which some historians attribute to his carved sculptures), to keep serious viewers coming back for second, even third looks. In Los Angeles, that seems to be joyfully the case.
As for New York, traditionally a tough town, it's nevertheless likely that the public's love affair with the star-crossed painter will resume in full when the Jewish Museum opens its own full-scale Modigliani retrospective in May.

HEADLINE: FILM; 
Playing the Horses (and the Horse People, Too)

BYLINE:  By JANE SMILEY; Jane Smiley's novels include "A Thousand Acres," "Moo" and "Horse Heaven." Her most recent is "Good Faith." She owns a racehorse named Darlin' Corey.

DATELINE: ACADIA, Calif. 

 BODY:
I WAS sitting with my horse trainer outside her office at Santa Anita racetrack. It was 101 degrees, and we were waiting. It was still and quiet. Most of the other trainers had already moved their horses to Del Mar for the summer meet. Between her barn and the one next door, a groom was walking a sleek mahogany bay colt. They paused at the water bucket, and the colt took a drink, then turned his narrow, elegant blaze and his large, expressive eyes toward us. "That's the big horse," said Alexis. "That's their horse."
 "AtswhatImtalknbout?" 
 "Yeah." 
He strode on, deliberate in the heat, the racehorse the "Seabiscuit" movie people bought a piece of just before he ran in this year's Kentucky Derby. His head was splendid, his neck curved perfectly, his walk was sinuous, his tail flowed long and silky. He was the picture of thoroughbred class. He didn't have a part in the movie.
What we were waiting for was the party to begin, the fundraising preview last month of "Seabiscuit" the movie, and soon enough, it did, at the restaurant the jockey George Woolf once owned, the Derby. The restaurant was jammed. A big black bus called the Presidential had brought one party up from Del Mar, and a 36-foot black Hummerlimousine had brought in another group. It looked not so much like a vehicle; more like a building. The jockey Chris McCarron, neat as you please in a champagne-colored sportshirt and shorts, greeted us at the door and handed us our favor -- a poster of the movie and a box containing three model horses, Seabiscuit, War Admiral and Pumpkin, the Biscuit's faithful companion. The food was jockey food -- smoked salmon, fruit, no bread or crackers. The crowd was an owners crowd, which means moneyed, but horsey. The men looked vaguely Republican, with a tinge of Vegas -- very smooth creased slacks and bright sportshirts, highly pressed. The women were lean and weathered, no chemical peels in evidence. No one said anything about the movie. What was there to say? It had all been said for them in the racing press, which had been hyping the movie since the spring with ads, articles and come-ons. Even The Daily Racing Form had put out a special flyer. All the hype suddenly seemed a little beneath this crowd, who were, after all, plenty sophisticated and plenty experienced, with a natural demeanor hopeful and skeptical in equal measure.
We went to the movie in buses. Those of us who had paid bottom dollar ($150) sat below the screen and gaped upward, which might have given us a jaded, or at least a dizzied view of the picture. More generous ones (and racing people are wonderfully generous) got reserved seats in the upper tiers. We filled two theaters and were told by the trainer Jenine Sahadi that we had ponied up 50,000 simoleons for laid-up jockeys, exercise riders and equine research. I was impressed.
It took 20 minutes to get to a horse, but when it did, the audience sighed audibly and settled into their seats. It was a mature audience. We remembered that there had been a Great Depression perfectly well and even recognized the picture of F.D.R. that accompanied Professor McCullough's explanation of the New Deal. I began to wonder just whom this "Seabiscuit" was aimed at. For a while it seemed aimed at the Bush administration and tax-cut economics.
The audience was patient. We knew horses were coming, and they did, but it wasn't until the entrance of Gary Stevens, making his acting debut as the jockey George Woolf, that we whooped and hooted and clapped in delight. After the death of the son of the rich Buick dealer Charles Howard (Jeff Bridges), the abandonment of the young jockey Red Pollard (Tobey Maguire) by his parents and the crash of the stock market, Gary Stevens's vibrant grace and energy livened things up quite a bit. 
We were suckers for the horses. When lazy old Seabiscuit stretched out for a nap in his pasture, we cooed. When Seabiscuit and Pumpkin curled up together with the dog, we chuckled. During the racing scenes, we perked up. The sound was especially good -- the jockeys spoke clearly amid the booming hooves and music was dispensed with. The horses blew and sweated -- you could hear that and almost feel it. A couple of the races lasted as long as real races -- a daring choice on the part of the filmmakers, but exciting and fun. My favorite moment was just before the start of the match race between Seabiscuit and War Admiral, when McCarron and Stevens, mounted on their horses, were on the screen at the same time. They had that look that great jockeys always have -- strong and lithe and intent. My trainer's favorite moment was right at the end, a long-shot from the middle of the track, down the harrowed stretch, past the finish line to the first turn. She said, "I've seen that so many times, hundreds of times galloping horses out there. It brought tears to my eyes."
During the closing credits, there was a lot of applause but even so, reviews were mixed (as they were when the real movie critics weighed in, too). One veterinarian and his family sat around until midnight, exclaiming over the movie. Gary Stevens told The Thoroughbred Times that he cried for two-and-a-half hours after he saw it. One man who was on our bus said that after all the hype, he expected it to be a lot better, and one woman told me: "The racing scenes were great, weren't they? But otherwise not enough drama." She was right. Somehow, the Jeff Bridges/Tobey Maguire/Chris Cooper story just didn't jell.
Perhaps they were too worthy. For one thing, Jeff Bridges as Seabiscuit's owner never does anything robber-baronish or even selfish. In the middle of the Depression, he refuses to lay off his workers. He makes speeches about the common man. He is not Ken Lay, Enron's former C.E.O. Samuel Riddle (played by Eddie Jones), the wealthy East Coast owner of War Admiral and Seabiscuit's enemy, is Ken Lay. I wouldn't have been surprised to hear that in addition to avoiding a race with Seabiscuit and insulting California racing, he is stealing pension plans on the side. But our self-made man, our cowboy trainer, our impoverished, beat-up jockey and our tiny horse gave off just a whiff of deadening Socialist realism. Too much high-mindedness and not enough drama.
THE next morning on the track, the post-mortem was more irreverent. "Can you imagine," said one trainer, "having the owner around all the time like that?" The other trainers shook their heads. "You know what Eddie said," my trainer recalled, referring to the late, great trainer Eddie Gregson. "He said about some guy: 'He's the best kind of owner. He's dead.' "
"We're too picky," said my vet. "So what if Tobey Maguire doctored the wrong leg when he had Seabiscuit out walking in the grass? So what if a vet would never go into a horse's stall alone and never come out and offer to euthanize a horse with a bowed tendon? That's Hollywood. Regular people won't notice. They'll like it. It's the best movie they ever made about racing."
As I said, racing people are generous. One man walked by and said: "Did you hear? The horse that played Seabiscuit, the one they auctioned for charity and got $13,000? He won his race at Ruidoso Downs yesterday." We all smiled.
I wondered about that horse, a little bay, the star of the movie. If it had been my movie, I would have had the camera linger over his face and body as if he were the most beautiful starlet in the world. I would have cut the history lesson to a minimum and shown the horse walking around the ring as if he were the big horse, swinging his head and flicking his ears, lazily switching his tail. I would have shown the light reflecting off his blooming coat and gotten regular people to understand that even before they win, we love them.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY; 
Cuba Tour Companies Add New (Last) Trips

BYLINE:  By SUSAN CATTO 

 BODY:
Time is running out for groups offering educational trips to Cuba. Since 1999, when the United States government began licensing companies to take groups on people-to-people educational exchanges, an estimated 50,000 Americans have participated in study trips to Cuba. But in March, the Treasury Department announced that it would no longer grant or renew educational-travel licenses unrelated to academic coursework. Many permits have already expired; the rest will run out by early next year. 
 "The bottom line with this particular license is it was frequently abused for travel that related to little more than tourism," said Taylor Griffin, a spokesman for the Treasury Department. 
 Many tour companies and cultural institutions regret the change of policy. "It's a shame," said Harriet Friedlander, whose company, Academic Arrangements Abroad, has planned Cuban trips for the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the American Folk Art Museum. "I would think the best thing we could do for the Cuban people would be to have cultured Americans interested in their country there for them to talk to. That whole chain of contacts will be gone with the abolition of these licenses." 
 Groups that still have valid licenses are rushing to add new departures to their schedules. The following are among those programs with space remaining. 
 The Center for Cuban Studies, (212) 242-0559, www.cubaupdate.org, a New York-based research group, offers weeklong Cuba Update trips examining the country's political, economic, religious and artistic institutions. Trips depart from New York City on Sept. 6, Oct. 11 and Nov. 8 and cost $2,500 a person for double rooms and $2,700 for singles. The Center also offers itineraries focusing on performing arts (Sept. 13 to 20; Oct. 18 to 25; Nov. 22 to 29), film (Sept. 20 to 27), architecture (Oct. 18 to 26) and the visual arts (Nov. 1 to 10; Nov. 10 to 20). Rates include air fare and some meals. 
 Elderhostel, (877) 426-8056, www.elderhostel.org, offering trips to travelers 55 and over (and younger companions), has four Cuba programs and more than 15 departures scheduled between October and December. There is a waiting list for double rooms on all trips, but single rooms are still available. The 11-night Cuba: Key to the Americas trip visits Havana, Vinales and Santiago de Cuba; participants study the country's cultural, geographical, agricultural and religious history. Eight departure dates are available between Oct. 20 and Dec. 8; the single-room rate is $3,375. A tour called An Exploration into Cuban Culture and History goes to Santa Clara, Trinidad and Havana and focuses on political, economic and cultural history. Five departures are offered between Nov. 8 and Dec. 6; single rooms are $3,101. Rates include air fare from Cancun and all meals. 
 Insight Cuba, (800) 935-2822, www.insightcuba.org, a program of the international volunteer organization Cross-Cultural Solutions, has more than 20 trips remaining. A one-week Havana-based jazz trip departs Sept. 13, Oct. 11, Nov. 8 and Dec. 13; prices start at $2,299 a person, double occupancy, including air fare from Miami, a Cuban visa and two meals a day; single supplement $175. Perspective, a two-week cultural tour, visits Havana, Pinar del Rio, Santa Clara, Trinidad, Remedios and Santiago de Cuba. Departures are Sept. 20, Oct. 25, Nov. 15, Dec. 6 and Dec. 13; rates start at $2,899, double occupancy, including two meals a day but not air fare or visa; single supplement $490. There is also a one-week Perspective trip departing Sept. 6, Oct. 18, Nov. 22, Dec. 6and Dec. 20; $1,799 a person, including two meals a day but not air fare or visa; single supplement, $245. 
 The National Trust for Historic Preservation, (800) 944-6847, Web site www.nationaltrust.org, offers a study tour called Cuba: Its Culture and Its People from Oct. 10 to 17. Participants explore the architecture of Havana, Trinidad, the Valley of the Sugar Mills and Cienfuegos. Tours depart from Miami and cost $3,975 a person based on double occupancy, with a $380 single supplement; membership in the National Trust costs $20. Rates include most meals but not air fare. 
 SalsaDanceCuba.org, (877) 912-3118, based in Boulder, Colo., will hold a dance and percussion program in Havana from Nov. 22 to 29. Cuban instructors will teach salsa and contemporary Latin dance and percussion techniques; cultural classes, dances and excursions to local nightclubs are also on the itinerary. The tour departs from Miami and costs $1,849 a person, double occupancy, or $2,099 for a single room. Rates include air fare from Miami and all meals. SUSAN CATTO

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
As Numbers of Screeners Fall, Airport Lines Grow

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PASSENGER traffic at the airports is rising a bit, because of the season and the end of major combat in Iraq, but the number of security screeners is falling, as the Transportation Security Administration "rightsizes" itself to fit budget mandates. One result is longer lines at the checkpoints.
 The T.S.A. had set a goal of no more than a 10-minute wait before a passenger enters the screening process. Robert Johnson, an agency spokesman, said that the average is around that. But "average" can hide the extremes, and airport officials say that lines can extend for more than an hour. The Atlanta, Denver, Des Moines, Fort Lauderdale, Pittsburgh, Phoenix and Seattle-Tacoma airports, among others, have sometimes seen very long waits, up to an hour and a half at Hartsfield-Atlanta, for example. 
 At Seattle-Tacoma, on two weekends in May the lines were so long that at times, "you'd walk in, in to the ticket counter, then back out to the garage to get on line," said Bob Parker, a spokesman for Sea-Tac. The problem, he said, was caused by a lack of screeners.
 Sea-Tac took matters into its own hands, Mr. Parker said. It hired airport personnel to replace some T.S.A. workers, "the ones who say, 'Good morning, thanks for flying, those look like Rockport shoes, they've all got steel shanks, put them in the X-ray,"' said Mr. Parker. That made the agency workers available to actually screen passengers. The airport also continuously monitors line length, and sometimes recommends to the agency that it shift screeners from a checkpoint with no line to another where a line is building, he said. The cost, $150,000 a month, will come out of airport revenues and will eventually be paid by travelers through airport charges, he said.
 After long lines developed this spring at Denver International Airport, Diana DeGette, who represents that city in Congress, sent a complaint letter to Tom Ridge, the homeland security secretary, calling for temporary assignment of extra screeners there and a delay in scheduled cutbacks. 
"These delays are intolerable and could harm both the regional economy and the airline industry," she said in a statement. "Of even greater concern, the long lines and personnel shortages put unnecessary pressure on screeners and on security." The T.S.A. said that screeners will not be pressured by the length of the line. 
 The agency plans a 19 percent cut of passenger- and baggage-screeners at the Denver airport, part of a nationwide effort to cut 6,000 screeners that began on April 1, when there were 55,600. The cuts are supposed to be completed by Sept. 30. Announcing the cuts, the T.S.A. promised that wait times would "remain low."
 But results are obvious around the country. At Dulles International Airport near Washington on the Sunday afternoon of the Independence Day weekend, lines at the security checkpoints stretched to more than a half hour, but at one checkpoint with three scanning lanes, two of them stood empty because of a lack of personnel.
 In other places, the problem involves equipment. Mr. Johnson said that on Monday mornings the lines at Hartsfield Atlanta Airport sometimes stretched for an hour and a half, although all the lanes were staffed. In Atlanta, as at other airports, it is difficult to add more lanes for screeners. 
 Airline executives, who are reluctant to appear publicly critical of the T.S.A., say that problems have cropped up for a mix of reasons, not all of them the agency's fault. One problem is that in the rush to install baggage screening systems by Dec. 31 of last year, the deadline set by Congress, the agency resorted to screening many bags by having technicians wipe them with pads, and then analyze the pads for signs of explosives. The job could be automated by using scanning machines instead, but installing those giant machines, and the conveyor belts needed to make effective use of them, has lagged, partly for budget reasons.
 The airlines also say that the Transportation Security Administration, as a federal agency, is not as attuned to the peaks and valleys of passenger traffic as the airlines are, and has hired too many full-time workers and not enough part-timers, who could be brought in for peak periods. The agency said it is planning to hire such workers. The airlines, wary of giving up competitive information, do not provide real-time data on their passenger loads to the federal government. But lately they are trying to keep the security agency advised of passenger levels, on an airport-by-airport basis. 
 And the summer may be inherently more difficult, because of "once-a-year travelers, who bring everything but the kitchen sink on the plane," one airline executive said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Can 'Smart Growth' Cut Parking Needs?

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
"I WANT that parking space -- and I want it now!"'
 Any New Jersey driver who frequents busy downtowns knows the feeling, says Darius Sollohub, an architecture professor at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, who studies parking issues. 
 "It's Friday night in Montclair, or Newark, or Jersey City, or Princeton," he said, "and all you care about at that moment is that you can't find a place to park. It's very frustrating."
The frustration translates to public pressure put on planners -- who put pressure on developers -- to provide as much new parking as possible whenever development or redevelopment occurs, Mr. Sollohub said. 
But some planners and developers working within the state's current so-called smart growth and transit-friendly policies are asking: Is the demand for parking space being reduced by these policies? If so, should state and local requirements for parkingspace actually be lowered when mass transit is available nearby?
In a city like Hoboken, where the rate of mass-transit users is high and where people mill around downtown on a Friday night rather than hover for parking spaces, Mr. Sollohub said, studies indicate only about one space per housing unit is needed. But state design standards call for nearly two spaces per unit.
In South Orange, where the 200-unit Gaslight Commons apartment complex opened last year with a required 360 parking spaces, the executive who supervised the development for Pennsylvania-based LCOR, Anthony L. Marchetta, said he now thought that was more car space than was needed.
The complex is 300 yards from a railroad station. "We took a census in our building," Mr. Marchetta said, "and found that nearly 65 percent of our residents take the train to work. About 60 percent of residents have one car, and the rest have two cars. Five people have no car."
Mr. Marchetta, who was a city planner for 13 years and who is a former member of the state Planning Commission, said he was aware of several state agencies that were beginning studies of development supported by the state's Transit Village program, which provides grants for the refurbishing of mass-transit stations and development of the areas around them. "I think that as the impact of the Transit Village and 'transit-friendly' programs is studied, it will show that much less parking is needed," he said.
THE amount of parking called for under the Residential Site Improvement Standards, set by the state Department of Community Affairs, varies with the type of apartment building, Mr. Marchetta said. For a low-rise garden apartment complex like Gaslight Commons, 1.8 spaces per one-bedroom unit and 1.9 spaces per two-bedroom unit are required. 
Seventy percent of the apartments at Gaslight Commons have one bedroom and the rest have two. There is one level of underground parking and also surface space for cars at Gaslight's two adjacent buildings. 
"If we had known going in that fewer parking spaces were needed, we could have done more with the outdoors," Mr. Marchetta said. "We would probably have been required to build the underground parking -- which is more expensive -- anyway. But right now, the only amenities out of doors are one swimming pool and one green space. We could have done more with more space."
As a developer, Mr. Marchetta said, he hates to see space wasted on unused parking. "The whole point," he said, "is to maximize use per square foot."
Mr. Marchetta worked as a planner with the city of New Brunswick and with Middlesex County before becoming a developer. He said he had often heard other developers say that parking was the biggest problem when trying to get a housing or commercial project approved in a populous northern Jersey community.
"In most cases, the only allowable solution," he said, is building a parking deck, "or going underground." He added, "There has got to be a better way."
Some new concepts and technology are entering the parking arena, noted Martin E. Robins of the Voorhees Transportation Institute at Rutgers University, who has worked with both New Jersey Transit and the state Department of Transportation in evaluating the impact of transit-related development. He mentioned a robotic parking structure in Hoboken that opened last year and uses computerized technology to park cars.
Extensively used in Europe, according to Mr. Sollohub, the architecture professor, roboticized structures cost roughly a third more to build than structures of similar capacity , but occupy much less land. The seven-story Garden Street Garage built by Robotic Parking System in Hoboken provides 312 spaces on a 100-foot-square lot. Cars are automatically assigned spaces, moved to them on pallets, and retrieved the same way.
In downtown Newark, where parking is always at a premium, two developers have been wondering if historic Washington Park might be dug up and reconstructed with parking underneath. "I was up on a roof one day, looking down at the people driving around looking for a spot," said Christian Benedetto of National Redevelopment, "and it hit me: Why not dig the way they did when they redeveloped Military Park a few blocks away?" 
Mr. Benedetto said he and Steven Greenberg of Heritage Management Company had "kicked the idea around," but not pursued it in earnest, partly because they thought the cost of construction and reconstruction might be prohibitive.
In Montclair, the idea of "shared parking" seems to be working well, in Mr. Sollohub's view. He has written a proposal to study parking around mass transit centers, including the lot adjacent to the Walnut Street railroad station in Montclair, in order to examine how design strategy can reduce the amount of parking needed.
At the Walnut Street station area developed by Steven Plofker -- who has also been named a co-developer of the former Hahne's department store site in downtown Montclair -- a parking lot serving rail commuters during the workday is shared by visitors to the soccer dome Mr. Plofker built next door to the station and by visitors to restaurants and shops along Walnut Street after commuters have gone home.
Walnut Street lies south of Montclair's downtown and is not as congested as the town's main artery, Bloomfield Avenue. In the downtown area, construction of a parking deck is scheduled to begin soon and both underground and surface space will be added when the Hahne's redevelopment project gets under way.
Montclair's township planner, Karen Kadus, said that the parking requirements for the Hahne's site were still being debated and refined, but currently stand at 1.3 spaces per apartment unit and 2.5 spaces per 1,000 square feet of commercial property. "Whatever it is, some people will say it's not enough," she said.
Mr. Sollohub, who lives in neighboring Glen Ridge, predicted continuing parking issues for Montclair and any town that tries to "build its way out of congestion."
"With transportation infrastructure," he said, "we've come to know that the more you provide, the more it becomes saturated. Like with traffic on the highway, if you add more lanes, then traffic increases. Parking is the same."
Mr. Marchetta, the planner and developer, said he was surprised at how few experts in parking theory and design there were in this country. "There is little knowledge concerning how public policies and grants really could reduce parking," he said. "Decisions are made by hundreds and hundreds of local planning boards in New Jersey, many of which have little familiarity with these issues."
"There needs to be more serious research," Mr. Marchetta added, "so we can all get a handle on this."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/New Dorp; 
Convenience Near Staten Island's Shore

BYLINE:  By JANICE FIORAVANTE

 BODY:
"WE spent a year and a half looking for a home, but we kept coming back to New Dorp," in part because of its convenient location, said Kevin Carney, who bought a five-bedroom ranch on Jacques Street in November 2001 for $360,000. 
 Mr. Carney notes that he and his wife, Joan, were drawn to the convenience of the train to the ferry, the express bus to Manhattan and shopping. In addition, it is just 20 minutes from Bay Ridge, where their parents live. In fact, the neighborhood reminds Mr. Carney a bit of Brooklyn, but the houses are not as close together. 
 Indeed, a block from the main commercial thoroughfares, the streets have a very residential character with stately trees, well-kept lawns and comfortable-looking homes. "I like its tree-lined streets and the detached houses -- ours is on a 50-by-100-foot lot," And the local elementary school, Public School 41, is around the corner, when the Carneys' son, 4 and daughter, 2, are ready. 
Twenty-five years ago, Joseph Markowski was drawn by similar considerations when he moved to New Dorp. "We had a two-year-old daughter, and my wife, Marie, was pregnant with our second daughter," he recalled. "We liked the location because it's convenient to stores; the train for public transportation is close by; and over the years, this has helped keep us here -- and the nice people in the community, too."
The midisland setting on the eastern shoreline also has its drawbacks. "The most dangerous intersection on Staten Island for traffic accidents is right in the center of the neighborhood at New Dorp Lane and Hylan Boulevard," said Mr. Markowski, president of the New Dorp Central Civic Association. The group's main concern, he said, is overdevelopment, which translates to more traffic. 
"It's a struggle, and the accelerated pace of building over the past year or two has made it more apparent," he explained. Increasingly, older homes are being purchased to be knocked down and replaced by two, four, even six semidetached homes, he said.
"It means where there may have been one, two or three cars to the one house, now there are that many multiplied by the number of houses," Mr. Markowski continued.
The recent flurry of construction is being attributed to a community zoning change that is expected to be enacted in November or December that would make it impossible to build attached housing. An environmental impact study is still being prepared. The proposed regulation would ultimately allow only one- or two-family detached homes to be built on Staten Island, rather than semidetached or town houses. "There has been a rush to build semidetached homes before the change goes into effect," said Edward Bruno, broker at Wolfe Realty.
Mr. Bruno added that there is considerable uncertainty about how this downzoning will affect home prices, but conventional wisdom is that prices may drop sharply in the short term because single-family homes will no longer be sought by developers aiming to build multiunit projects. "A house that sold for $700,000 would probably sell for only $400,000 to $450,000 next year," Mr. Bruno said. 
City Councilman James Oddo said that while the zoning change would offer less economic incentive for "teardowns," it would still afford the opportunity to build two detached houses on a lot, right up to the property line. This "is the soft underbelly of downzoning," he said. "It means new density problems." He expects the Task Force on Overdevelopment on the Island, which has been appointed by the mayor, to address this.
WHERE new homes have been constructed, prices have been rising, Mr. Bruno said. "There were six town houses built on Winham Avenue a year and a half ago that sold for $300,000," he said. "Today, they're worth $379,000." 
The town houses are in New Dorp Beach, the area closest to the Atlantic Ocean, one of four subdistricts in the community. The others are New Dorp Heights, the northern tip of the neighborhood; the commercial district, which centers on New Dorp Lane, New Dorp Plaza and Hylan Boulevard; and the older tree-lined central area, surrounding the Staten Island Railway station.
New Dorp Beach, with summer bungalows modified to be year-round homes, is next to Miller Field, part of Gateway National Recreation Area, which was an airfield before and during World War II. The park is used today for soccer, baseball, softball and other recreation. "Saturdays, Miller Field is packed with thousands of kids and their parents," Mr. Markowski said.
A representative street in the area is Seafoam Street, so narrow that only one car can navigate it. Tightly packed small bungalows line its sidewalks.
New Dorp Heights is the hilly inland part of the community bounded by the greenery of the Moravian Cemetery, as well as High Rock Park Conservation Area. Colonials, Capes, ranches, high ranches and custom-built detached homes dot the area. Mr. Bruno recently sold a 43-by-100-foot lot on St. Stephens Place to a builder who plans to build a $700,000 30-by-42-foot side-hall colonial with four bedrooms and four baths. 
It sits across from the Gustave Mayer House, a New York City landmark at 2475 Richmond Road. According to "Holden's Staten Island," a new book by the borough historian, Richard Dickenson, it was built in 1855 or 1856 in the Italian villa style, a boxy, massive home with an arcaded porch, deep-bracketed eaves and a square cupola. Mr. Mayer was a confectioner who invented the sugar wafer. The home is still privately owned. 
The Heights are also home to the New Dorp Light House, a privately owned home at 25 Boyle Street. This 1854 clapboard cottage contains a tall square tower. For 90 years, the lighthouse, also known as Moravian Light, served as a beacon for ships. 
The central area is an older part of New Dorp with large trees canopying the streets. Here the homes are 70 to 80 years old and include Tudors, ranches and colonials. Several Tudor homes with four apartments per building are at Clawson Street and Beach Avenue. And Tysen's Park Apartments on Tysen's Lane is the only large-scale apartment development; it is a federally subsidized 1,006-unit complex in eight six-story buildings.
The commercial district, running from Tysens Lane to New Dorp Lane on Hylan Boulevard, includes Hylan Shopping Plaza with a Pathmark supermarket, a Kmart, movie theaters and a Toys "R" Us. The New Dorp Post Office, SportsFest, Bowling on the Green, the Gap and Starbucks are other outlets on a shopping corridor that stretches between Hylan Boulevard and Mill Road.
Along New Dorp Lane are the recently refurbished New Dorp Regional Library; a number of restaurants, including La Strada, Taste of India, King's Chef, the French Tart bakery and cafe, and Sedutto's ice cream parlor; and an array of local stores like the Luggage Shop, and Hidden Cottage Hill of Beans for coffee, teas and gift baskets. A rehabilitation project about five years ago added small, old fashioned street lights and new sidewalks "to give a small-town feel to the Lane," Mr. Markowski said.
Residents express considerable satisfaction with schools in the neighborhood. P.S. 41 on Clawson Street, which had 737 students this past year, offers prekindergarten through Grade 5. In 2003, 74.2 percent of students in the third, fourth and fifth grade were at or above grade level in language arts, while 75 percent of students in the third and fifth grades, and 73.3 percent for Grade 4, met or exceeded math standards. The New York City Council Sports and Arts Summer Camp free program is in full swing through Aug. 7, offering handball, hip hop dancing, aerobics, lacrosse, soccer, double dutch and basketball.
The George L. Egbert Intermediate School 2 on Midland Avenue, with 1,200 students last year, had an unusually large graduating class in June, 408 students. The school has been experiencing rapid growth; in past years graduating classes averaged around 300. The school serves a diverse population of students, with 28 languages spoken, including Uzbek, Urdu and Hindi. A Mid-Island Beacon Program allows students to use the school until 10 p.m., for tutoring, sports and homework assistance. 
Staten Island Technical High School at 485 Clawson Street, with 715 students, is a college prep school that accepts students on the basis of test scores and grades. Almost all of its 2003 graduating class of 170 will be attending college. The school specializes in math, science and engineering; offers Russian as its only foreign language; and runs exchange programs with Russia. The new principal, Vincent Maniscalco, has expanded the performing arts programs with dance studios and band programs. This past spring, students offered "Bat Boy" as their musical production.
New Dorp High School, at 465 New Dorp Lane, with 1,800 students, offers advanced placement courses in biology, calculus and history. It has a Future Teachers Academy, where seniors take education courses at St. John's University and the College of Staten Island; an Institute for the Arts, which includes drama, music and art; an American studies and law program; and an Executive Intern program for students to spend a semester outside the classroom as interns to executive sponsors in business. Of 360 graduating seniors, 85 percent will attend four-year colleges and 10 percent will go to two-year colleges.
Religious schools in the neighborhood are Our Lady Queen of Peace, offering kindergarten through eighth grade, and the Christian Academy, offering prekindergarten to Grade 8.
New Dorp, originally Nieuwe Dorp, which means new town, dates to the 1670's, when Dutch Walloon and French Huguenot farmers moved here looking for more fertile land. It remained in the hands of large landholders until late in the 19th century, when more homes and businesses were established.

The development is named the Rose and Crown after a tavern that stood there from 1665 to 1854. A plaque diagonally across New Dorp Lane from the condos notes that at the tavern, the Declaration of Independence was read to British officers on July 9, 1776. HEADLINE: Surge in Mortgage Activity Creates New Work, for Now 

BYLINE:  By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU

 BODY:
AS a salesman for a San Francisco software company that made products for the energy industry, Kevin Krueger was in a career tied to two struggling industries. So it came as no surprise in October when he and the bulk of the company's sales staff received pink slips. With dim job prospects in technology, Mr. Krueger, 32, decided to focus on growth industries. 
 After a trip back to the East Coast to visit his family, Mr. Krueger contacted Champion Mortgage. In December, he became a loan officer in the company's office in Parsippany, N.J. 
 "It was easy for me to transfer my skills in finance and sales to mortgages," said Mr. Krueger, who worked as a broker before jumping into high tech. He said he was on track to exceed the six-figure income he earned when software sales were strong. "Everybody always needs a home," he said.
At a time when many financial firms, particularly those on Wall Street, are cutting back, low interest rates have sparked an explosion in home purchases and refinancing, and companies that provide or process mortgages are expanding rapidly. 
The boom could well be short lived. With interest rates rising sharply, mortgage refinancing activity has slowed in the last few weeks. In mid-July, as rates were climbing, the Mortgage Bankers Association released a study predicting that mortgage lending would reach a record $3.4 trillion this year but drop to $1.9 trillion in 2004 and $1.5 trillion in 2005. Still, the current demand for mortgages is leading many mortgage companies in the greater New York area and throughout the United States to seek workers to keep up with the demand for loans, say economists and others watching the industry. This is particularly true for companies focused on new mortgages rather than refinancing, they said.
Nationwide, mortgage-related jobs jumped nearly 16 percent, to 353,700 in 2002, up from 297,200 jobs in 2001, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. And the industry added 22,800 jobs from January through May, according to preliminary figures from the bureau.
Job postings in the real estate category on Monster.com, the online job listing service, increased 61 percent from June 2002 to this June, and rose 15 percent over the last month of that period, said Kevin Mullins, a spokesman for the company.
"You can thank Alan Greenspan" for the low interest rates, said Michael A. Goldstein, associate professor of finance at Babson College in Babson Park, Mass. "It's been a massive subsidy for themortgage industry and the mortgage people are making a boatload of money."
If rates stay relatively low, Mr. Goldstein said, the mortgage sector will continue to be one of the economy's employment bright spots.
In the New York area, companies seeking new employees are willing to pay anywhere from $25,000 for entry-level data processing jobs to $70,000 and up for underwriters.
The New York Mortgage Company, a privately owned mortgage lender, wants to add 150 workers to its Manhattan offices and another 40 in Melville on Long Island, according to Steve Schnall, president and chief executive. The company recently tripled its office space. 
"For the last several years the mortgage industry has been robust and we've been hiring aggressively, but in the last 24 months, and in particular the last 6 months, things have taken off," Mr. Schnall said. "The biggest challenge is finding qualified staff because there's so much competition among banks and mortgage lenders."
Adding to the staff, he said, has become a full-time effort this year, and for the first time the company has sought the help of recruiters. The competition has also driven up salaries about 10 percent across the board since last year, he said.
Claudette Greenstein, 32, came to New York Mortgage in January and is working at the company's office in Bridgehampton, after time spent in magazine and newspaper advertising sales. "After Sept. 11, the publishing industry went down drastically," she said. This year, she said, she expects to make 25 percent to 30 percent more than she was making in publishing last year.
Marcia Kaufman, the chief operating officer of Preferred Empire Mortgage, which is based in Melville, said the company would like to hire 80 workers to add to a staff of 95. In 2000, Preferred had only 30 employees.
There are a jumble of titles in the mortgage business, and similar jobs sometimes have different names. At some companies, a mortgage broker may handle some of the paperwork involved in the mortgage process, while other companies have a team of processors and closing coordinators to expedite the process.
Michael Mahfouz, northeast divisional manager and senior vice president of G.M.A.C. Mortgage, based in Horsham, Pa., said he liked to promote from the entry-level clerical ranks when seeking mortgage processors and closers. Processors, who can make $40,000 with overtime, are required to have a high school degree but most have finished college, said Mr. Mahfouz, who oversees retail lending and staff in the Northeast. 
Marcell Jones, 24, was a receptionist for an entertainment company for three years and joined New York Mortgage in January as an auditor in the post-closing department. "I knew nothing about mortgages," she said. To learn the ropes, Ms. Jones spent two months working side by side with another auditor in her department. She is now making $16 an hour, compared with the $11 an hour she was making as a receptionist.
The flush times in the mortgage business will not last indefinitely, particularly if interest rates continue their upward climb. Professor Goldstein of Babson College likened the growth in the mortgage industry to the Internet bubble.
"Once the rates go up, and the big volume of refinances stops, the Ferris wheel will stop," he said. Many companies will then begin to lay off workers, he said, as many did in 1999 and 2000 when rates hovered around 8 percent and demand for mortgages was limited. 
But many workers in today's job market have come to expect volatility. "No one can say what you'll be doing for the rest of your career," said Mr. Krueger, the former software sales representative. "Right now," he said about the mortgage business, "it's a great place to be."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Cathleen Cahill, Andrew Sandoval-Strausz

 BODY:
Cathleen Denise Bridget Cahill, a daughter of Pamela Davis Cahill and Dennis R. Cahill of Bayside, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew K. Sandoval-Strausz, the son of Dr. 
Ivan K. Strausz of New York and the late Cecilia Sandoval Londono. The Rev. Dr. Abraham Waya, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Carson Mansion in Eureka, Calif., which houses the Ingomar Club. 
 Ms. Cahill, 29, is keeping her name. She is a doctoral candidate in history at the University of Chicago and is the pre-doctoral fellow in American Indian studies at Michigan State University in East Lansing. His father is an obstetrician and gynecologist at Metropolitan Hospital in New York, and an associate professor of clinical obstetrics and gynecology at New York Medical College. HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Suzan Atesoglu, Michael Brassard

 BODY:
Suzan Atesoglu, a daughter of Jane Bentz Atesoglu and Dr. H. Sonmez Atesoglu of Potsdam, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael James Brassard, the son of Barbara A. Durkin and Michael G. Brassard, both of Hannawa Falls, N.Y. Kevin Patnode, a town justice in Plattsburgh, N.Y., officiated at the Whiteface Club, a resort in Lake Placid, N.Y.
 Mrs. 
Brassard, 27, teaches studio art at Mountain Lakes High School in Mountain Lakes, N.J. She graduated from Hamilton College and received a Master of Fine Arts degree in ceramic sculpture from the Rochester Institute of Technology. Her father is a professor of economics at Clarkson University in Potsdam. Her mother is an administrative nurse for Medlink of Northern New York, a home health-care service based in Potsdam. 
 Mr. Brassard, 28, is a salesman, in East Hanover, N.J., for the construction equipment division of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, the industrial equipment manufacturer. He graduated from Clarkson. His mother is a nurse supervisor in the radiation oncology unit of the Warner Cancer Treatment Center in Potsdam. His father is the corporate sales director for the Howland Pump and Supply Company, a distributor in Ogdensburg, N.Y.
