HEADLINE: A Suicide and Uncertainty in Korea 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: SEOUL, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
In life, Chung Mong Hun was this capitalist nation's economic ambassador to the Communist North, negotiating for South Korean tour buses to drive across the demilitarized zone, setting off fireworks to inaugurate North Korea's first industrial park, and posing with the North's reclusive leader, Kim Jong Il.
 All that abruptly ended when Mr. Chung's body was found Monday morning below an open window of his 12th-floor office at the headquarters of his troubled company, Hyundai Asan. Since then, Koreans have watched every turn of the case, fascinated by a prominent clan that is sometimes called the Korean Kennedys. 
 Their business fortune once made people call this country the Republic of Hyundai. Seventy years after the clan's patriarch arrived in Seoul as a construction worker, the Hyundai name is on South Korea's biggest car company and biggest shipbuilding company. The family's political fortune was less favorable; two members failed as presidential candidates. And on a personal level, the Chung clan's happiness has been marred by suicides and untimely deaths. 
But for North Korea, deeply suspicious of foreign investors, the loss of Mr. Chung may further slow the isolated nation's emergence from nearly 60 years of Communism. Hyundai has hemorrhaged millions of dollars annually on the cross-border tourism project, largely because North Korea dragged its feet for five years on allowing buses to cross the border.
On Tuesday, North Korea responded to Mr. Chung's death by indefinitely suspending tourist visits to the Hyundai-run resort.
"His death, in fact, cannot be regarded as a suicide," North Korea's Asia-Pacific Peace Committee, the state agency that was Hyundai's economic partner, said. "It was murder committed by the sword called 'special inspection' illegally engineered" by South Korean conservatives, referring to government investigations of Mr. Chung. The North postponed two economic cooperation meetings scheduled for this week.
While the suicide notes, the family history and Mr. Chung's exhaustion from repeated interrogations by prosecutors in a bribery case left little doubt about his suicide, question marks do hang over the future of inter-Korean economic cooperation.
"Knowing how personalistic all these inter-Korean exchanges are, I can only be guardedly pessimistic," Alexander Mansourov, a North Korea expert in Hawaii who was an economic officer in the Soviet Embassy in Pyongyang in the late 1980's, said Tuesday.
Others say that projects already established will sputter along, but new ones will falter. "For the projects already settled by the North and South Korean governments, I see no change, no problem," Dong Yong Seung, head of the North Korea team at the Samsung Economic Research Institute in Seoul, said in an interview Tuesday. "But I think there will be some problems for projects in the pipeline."
South Korean officials are tumbling over themselves this week to assure that there will be continuity for these cross-border investments, which are rare market-economy islands in what, until recently, has been the world's most statist sea.
"The government will make positive efforts so the inter-Korean economic projects proceed as intended by the deceased," said President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea, who interrupted his vacation to issue a statement. He cited the Kumgang tourism project, in which Hyundai is thought to have invested nearly $1 billion since it opened in 1998, and the Kaesong industrial park, which Mr. Chung inaugurated on June 30.
Jeong Se Hyun, South Korea's unification minister and point man for North-South contacts, gave a radio interview, assuring that Mr. Chung's death "will not specifically affect Hyundai Asan's joint inter-Korean projects because they are being carried out on a systematic basis, not on a personal basis."
But Mr. Chung's five brothers, who each run a Hyundai company, have all declined to bail out Hyundai Asan. Officers at the Hyundai Motor Group have said they make investment decisions based on profit potential, pointedly noting that 46 percent of their shareholders are foreigners.
"Chung Mong Hun's death puts a huge question mark over all the future of the investment in North Korea," Michael Breen, author of the book, "The Koreans," said today. "When he looked at North Korea, he thought of the old way the Koreans made business: nation-building, and not primarily looking at profit. You bribe where you have to, you borrow where you have to, you go into debt, but in the end, the result is worth it. Well, most companies here can't operate like that anymore."
In North Korea's system of one-man rule, where economic profit and legal contracts are alien concepts, Hyundai was able to make deals based on a personal bond forged between Chung Ju Yung, the clan patriarch, and Mr. Kim, North Korea's absolute leader. A peasant migrant from northern Korea, Mr. Chung caught Mr. Kim's fancy in 1998 when he herded 1,001 cows across a land bridge at the demilitarized zone. Mr. Chung, who died two years ago, said he was repaying North Korea 1,000 times over for the "loan" of a cow he had "borrowed" from his father to pay for his ticket south. 
Despite this bond, Mr. Chung and his son paid steep bribes -- $400 million by the son's admission -- for approval of seven projects by North Korea. Even then, progress was slow. Last week, Mr. Chung won permission for tour buses to start crossing the demilitarized zone this September, nearly five years after the tourism project opened and weeks after South Korea's conservative- controlled National Assembly voted to cut the project off from further government subsidies, which totaled $18 million last year. 
Conservatives saw the project as a cash cow that funneled Pyongyang money that could be used for nuclear weapons. More to the liking of all South Koreans is straightforward inter-Korean trade, which jumped 25 percent in the first half of this year, to $269 million.
The industrial park at Kaesong, also a Hyundai Asan venture, seems to make more economic sense. Situated 42 miles north of Seoul, just over the demilitarized zone, the park is intended to wed North Korea's cheap labor with South Korean technology and capital. The park is expected to employ 22,000 workers by 2007; the average wage is to be $95 a month.
With South Korea trying to double its per capita income to $20,000 by the end of this decade, industrial parks could divert to North Korea some of South Korea's investment in low-wage factories that now goes to China. Even though North Korea stands to benefit by taxing salaries in Kaesong, it took the government four years to approve the project, and work has yet to begin.
"I was in Kaesong a week ago, there were a lot of South Koreans there, still talking about details," said Tony Michell, president of Euro-Asian Business Consultancy, a British company that does business in North Korea. "They are checking the soils and surveying. Work is continuing on the road and railroad."
North Korea, which long enjoyed bottling up South Korea for strategic reasons, now spies lucrative opportunities as gatekeeper for rail, gas and oil connections between South Korea and Russia. If North Korea's nuclear program can be put back under international controls and peace is fully established on the peninsula, Russia wants to lead a $3.3 billion investment to link the Trans-Siberian Railroad and Trans-Koreanrailroads, allowing cargo to travel from Pusan, on South Korea's southern tip, to markets in Western Europe.
While progress is slow, foreign visitors to North Korea report a gradual acceptance of markets and foreigners. Last summer, price controls and rationing were dropped, moves that set off triple-digit price inflation. Two months ago, a directive went out to all towns to build district markets. 
"The government simply could not deliver the goods and services it used to deliver," Marcus Noland, North Korea expert for the Institute for International Economics, said from Washington. "Instead of eradicating markets, they are trying to control them, to regularize them. I don't get the impression that this is because they have seen the light and they want to have a market economy."
But through the cracks of the ailing state economy, new businesses are sprouting: restaurants, hair salons, kitchen gardens, smuggling people to China. Residential real estate increasingly is in private hands.
"There is much more openness to foreigners," said Kathi Zellweger, who oversees food aid for Caritas, the Christian charity. "The fear is gone. We can ask questions and discuss things. People are much more forthcoming."

HEADLINE: Pension Overhaul Wins Key Vote in Brazil 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva scored his first major legislative success today since taking office in January, winning resounding approval in the lower house of Congress to overhaul Brazil's debt-ridden public pension system.
 Despite strong opposition from workers in the public sector and the more extreme fringes of his own Workers Party, Mr. da Silva, who canceled an African trip to stay in Brasilia and shepherd the bill through Congress, marshaled enough support to carry the initial vote in the lower house by 358 to 126, with 9 abstentions. 
 The government needed 309 votes, or a three-fifths majority, to pass the bill, as it required altering the 1998 Constitution. Producing a compromise on the issue has taken up much of the government's energy during its first seven months in power. 
After the vote, Luiz Dulci, one of Mr. da Silva's chief aides, said the president believed that "the country has won because Brazil needs these reforms to start growing again, to create jobs and create wealth."
The long-awaited bill to tackle the pension system's chronic $20 billion annual deficit must now be passed point-by-point in the lower house before heading to the Senate, but the comfortable government majority in the predawn vote sent a strong positive signal to markets.
"This is clearly good news," said Doug Smith, chief economist for the Americas at Standard Chartered in New York. "We expected there would be some bumps, but the government initially aimed high and so could afford to make some compromises."
In recent days, the real slid against the dollar and Brazilian bonds fell as investors worried that the president would cave in on one or more of the reform's cornerstones.
The currency was languishing at 3.06 to the dollar today, its weakest level since mid-April, though traders said a debt rollover, rather than any pessimism about pension reform, was dragging the real down. Brazil's country risk -- a barometer of investor confidence measured by how much the country must pay over United States Treasury bonds to tap the market -- fell from over 900 basis points last week to 876 today.
Mr. da Silva, a former union leader, was forced to dilute his plans to end decades of privilege for public retirees after civil servants staged a disruptive strike last month.
As deputies prepared to vote Tuesday afternoon, police in Brasilia had to block the entrances to the congressional building to keep out hundreds ofprotesters. Disgruntled workers, estimated by police at 20,000 to 25,000, marched in Brasilia today, with some kicking in windows of the congressional building.
Ultimately, the bill passed with its main points -- a controversial salary ceiling for judges, taxing pensions over 1,200 reais ($400) a month and bringing taxes on private-sector pensions in line with those for the public sector -- more or less intact.
The reform should make it easier for the government to meet payments on its $283 billion public debt and free cash for programs to reduce the country's social inequalities.
The government has indicated it could use the savings, for example, to give basic social security coverage to some 40 million Brazilians working in the informal economy.
Ricardo Berzoini, the minister of social security, has said he expects the change to save $3 billion over the next three years and $17 billion through 2028. Even watered down, the bill is expected to save Brazil $16 billion by the end of the decade. Fearing a showdown with the governors of Brazil's cash-short states, the government has postponed voting on an overhaul of the country's tax system until the end of the year.
But the most urgent problem is kick-starting the ailing economy.
After raising interest rates early this year to 26.5 percent to rein in inflation, the central bank started easing monetary policy last month. But the overnight interest rate is still 24.5 percent, meaning consumers and small businesses must pay some 80 percent a year for a loan.
Analysts expect the economy to have shrunk for two straight quarters this year, while industrial production in June slumped 2.6 percent compared with May and was 2.1 percent below June 2002 levels. Unemployment has spiraled to over 20 percent in Sao Paulo, Brazil's industrial heartland.
Besides a further easing of rates, the government could reduce banks' minimum reserves to reflate the economy, but analysts say more reforms would be of more help in the longer term.
"We don't expect to see reforms every day, but it would be good to see progress on a monthly basis," said Mr. Smith of Standard Chartered.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 11, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in World Business on Thursday about the approval of pension legislation in Brazil misstated the date of the country's constitution, which the measure altered. It was 1988, not 1998.

HEADLINE: A Smoky Bar In New York? It's Just TV, Bloomberg Says 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
A new sitcom called "Whoopi," starring guess who, takes place in New York City and is being filmed in New York City. Its newly built sets on Stage H of Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens look very New Yorkish indeed -- with one exception that became readily apparent when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg dropped by yesterday.
 There are ashtrays on the tables of the bar set. 
 Not to worry, said Whoopi Goldberg, who is not only the show's star but also its executive producer. Asked about the habits of the character she plays -- described in promotional material as a "cigarette-smoking, alcohol-drinking, menopausal and especially opinionated hotelier" -- Ms. Goldberg held up a blank check.
"I have my checks ready," she said as she shared a microphone at a news conference with Mayor Bloomberg, the prime force behind the strict new smoking ban that has exiled ashtrays from real city bars. "So that when we're shooting and we find that within the scene someone has to smoke, I will be writing a check to the city of New York for that right."
Mayor Bloomberg, who was on hand to praise the show for filming in New York City, noted that there were exceptions to the ban when it came to actors in shows. 
He said the show, which is to be shown on NBC this fall, employs 250 people and is expected to pump $13 million into the local economy. And he said ABC was planning to film another show, starring Kelly Ripa, in the city. But the mayor did take issue with the name of Ms. Goldberg's show, "Whoopi."
"Now, I don't know how you can go and name something after yourself," said Mr. Bloomberg, the majority owner of the Bloomberg L.P. financial information company, the seller of computer terminals known as Bloombergs, and the author of "Bloomberg by Bloomberg." 
"People do that, I'm just shocked."

HEADLINE: Read His Lips: Do They Say Repeal All Those New Taxes? 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg casts an eye toward the 2005 mayoral elections by traveling around the city more and holding ever-more-elaborate photo opportunities, he is beginning to hone his message in an area that he is particularly sensitive about: taxes.
 Mr. Bloomberg, after all, ran for mayor in 2001 as a no-new-taxer. He mailed out campaign literature proclaiming that "the last thing N.Y.C. needs now is higher taxes," and, after he won, said in his inaugural address, "We cannot raise taxes." Then he began to govern and, faced with enormous deficits, raised the property tax, sales tax and income tax. 
 Now, after taking plenty of political heat for raising taxes, Mr. Bloomberg is trying to repair the damage. His message now is that he was able to save key city services by raising taxes, that the city is now emerging from the worst of the crisis thanks to his stewardship, and, above all, that he understands the pain that the higher taxes caused.
But in one area, his message is still a work in progress: will the taxes be lowered?
The mayor sounded a new note of optimism on that count last week when he told a state board that monitors the city's finances that all three taxes could be repealed. He said that he was "reasonably confident" that all three tax increases he pushed through -- would be "temporary."
Two of those taxes -- the sales tax and the income tax increases -- were always meant to be temporary. But his decision to describe the 18.5 percent property tax increase, which nets the city $1.7 billion a year, as "temporary" was new. This week, the mayor's communications director, William T. Cunningham, sought to clarify that remark, explaining that the mayor should have said that he would like to see the city's economy grow to the point where the property tax increase could be at least reduced.
That was the theme that the mayor stuck to yesterday, although he continued to hold out the hope that he could leave office with taxes lower than they were when he entered it, which again suggested that a full repeal was still a possibility. 
"I would like to leave office in six years with taxes lower than they were when I came into office and the city's economy in better shape," he said at a news conference in Queens.
Asked how likely it was that he would be able to lower the property tax, Mr. Bloomberg said, "I don't know how to assess it." (He made his remarks before it was learned that a state board had moved to block a municipal bond deal that is crucial to the city's efforts to balance its budget this year.)
Mr. Bloomberg did not allow that he misspoke last week before the board, contradicting the statement of his own communications director.
But the mayor did try to show his empathy for the people paying higher taxes.
"It's easy for people to just talk about taxes in the abstract, but the fact of the matter is, for people who have families, or don't have families, people who work for a living, taxes are a great burden," Mr. Bloomberg said. "They are unfortunately a necessity of life, and when you have to make the compromise between safe streets and taxes, I stood up and said this is what we should do."

HEADLINE: Pataki Blocks Deal Crucial to City Plan To End Fiscal Crisis 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
In a direct rebuke to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Gov. George E. Pataki and State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi moved today to block a municipal bond deal that is critical to the city's efforts to close its $6.4 billion budget gap this year.
 The vote by an obscure but powerful three-member board threw into chaos the city's plan to solve its financial crisis, possibly depriving it of up to $500 million a year in savings through 2008. 
 The city had hoped to achieve those savings by having the state take over its debt left over from the 1970's financial crisis. Mr. Pataki opposed the idea, but the State Legislature overrode his veto in May. 
The vote to kill the plan was made by the board of New York's Local Government Assistance Corporation, which the governor, a Republican, effectively controls; two of the board's three members are appointed by him, and the other one is Mr. Hevesi, a Democrat. The move comes while Mr. Bloomberg and fiscal monitors have been saying that the worst of the city's budget crisis is probably behind it.
Mayor Bloomberg said last night that he would challenge the board's action in court, igniting what promises to become intense negotiations between City Hall and Albany.
"It is disappointing that after all the difficulties New Yorkers have faced to get us through the fiscal crisis, L.G.A.C. wants to saddle the people of New York City with even more of a burden in these tough times," Mr. Bloomberg said in a written statement.
The two-paragraph statement by Mr. Bloomberg still did not mention the governor by name. Leaders in the State Legislature, though, sharply criticized Mr. Pataki for opposing their efforts to help the city.
"It is only the continuation of his attempt to try to hurt the city in any way possible, and like a child who comes to a game with his ball and does not like the results, he takes the ball and goes home," said Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Assembly speaker. "The override of his budget veto is what he is still fighting."
Mr. Silver added, "This looks like a direct attack on his fellow Republican, the mayor of the City of New York, who, in previous attacks, has turned the other cheek and refused to criticize the governor."
Today's events raised questions about whether a rift had developed between Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bloomberg, those on both sides of the political aisle said. City officials said they were not warned of Albany's pending action and were taken by surprise.
As of late today, the mayor and other city officials were scheduled to hold a joint, unrelated news conference with the governor at a city park on Thursday; by the evening, the event had been canceled.
A response from the corporation's board, sent by e-mail last night by Kevin C. Quinn, a spokesman for the State Division of the Budget, seemed to underline just how fierce any fight could become: "It is unfortunate that the city has chosen to attack the Local Government Assistance Corporation board rather than work cooperatively with state officials and the Legislature to provide the budget relief New York City needs in a fiscally responsible and legal manner that doesn't burden taxpayers with billions of dollars in new costs."
For weeks, the governor and Mr. Hevesi have condemned the municipal bond plan as a bit of fiscal chicanery, saying it would stretch out the payment of debt left over from the city's 1970's fiscal crisis until the year 2034, or beyond.
The governor has continued that stance despite the pleas of Mayor Bloomberg to allow the deal to stand. Mr. Hevesi, a former city comptroller, said he decided the deal was not in the state's best fiscal interests.
When asked if the move was intended as a message to steer potential bond buyers on Wall Street away from the deal, Mr. Hevesi said: "I think any responsible investor is going to say, 'If I take these bonds, how is it backed up? Who is going to reimburse?' That's a fair question."
Under the plan, approved by state lawmakers last spring, the state would allow the city to create a new local development corporation. That entity would be allowed to borrow money to pay off the remaining bonds issued by the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created in the 1970's to help the city out of its financial crisis.
The state would then pay the city $170 million a year, probably for about 30 years, to pay off the debt service on the new bonds. The state money would come from the Local Government Assistance Corporation, which gets its money from the state sales tax. The city would then not have to spend about $2.5 billion over the next five years paying off its remaining 1970's debt.
A city official said the issue was far from over. The mayor wanted to market his bonds on Wall Street next week, and on Tuesday, Standard & Poor's Ratings Service assigned a preliminary AA rating to the bonds and expressed confidence that issuing them would be constitutional. Now, the Bloomberg administration will speak with people at Goldman Sachs, the lead investment banker on the deal, to determine how and whether to proceed with the financing. "The city is analyzing its options," said Edward Skyler, a spokesman for the mayor.
City Hall's legal theory has been that because the financing arrangement was completed as part of the state budget, it is unimpeachable, so the state corporation cannot block it.
In May, the governor said this part of the Legislature's budget had been improperly drafted, and was therefore unconstitutional. One legislative aide said it appeared that the governor was now trying to use the state corporation to underscore that point.
The move was also a direct rebuke to leaders in the State Legislature, who saw the refinancing plan as a more palatable alternative than, for instance, taxing commuters who work in New York City, a measure Mr. Bloomberg advocated.
John E. McArdle, a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican State Senate majority leader, struck a conciliatory note, saying the Senate hoped the issue could be resolved in a budget cleanup bill. But, Mr. McArdle said, "we still support the basic agreement that has the state relieving the city of these payments."

HEADLINE: Movie Star In, Senator Out For Recall Race in California 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY with CHARLIE LeDUFF; David E. Sanger contributed to this article.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
The recall election on Gov. Gray Davis of California took stunning turns today, as one of the state's most respected elected officials, Senator Dianne Feinstein, announced that she would not run to replace Mr. Davis, and Arnold Schwarzenegger, a politically untested movie star, announced that he would.
 As extraordinary bookends on a day of fast-moving events, the two decisions could not have been more dissimilar in style and substance. Public opinion polls have identified Ms. Feinstein, a Democrat, and Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, as among the most popular alternatives to Mr. Davis, who faces a recall vote on Oct. 7. 
 The developments, which also included the formal start of the candidacy of the columnist Arianna Huffington, had setoff a panic among many Democratic officials, who are searching for a fallback candidate should Governor Davis lose the recall. 
Mr. Schwarzenegger, who has been spending most of the past several weeks promoting his newest "Terminator" movie, made his intentions known before a cheering television audience at a taping in Burbank of the "Tonight" show with Jay Leno.
Instead of talking about issues like nuclear proliferation and appropriations, as Ms. Feinstein did, Mr. Schwarzenegger made light of his decision to run while joking with Mr. Leno that it was the toughest one that he had made since deciding to get a bikini wax.
He did address the main question in the recall, saying: "The man that is failing the people more than anyone is Gray Davis. He is failing them terribly, and this is why he needs to be recalled, and this is why I am going to run for governor."
Anxious members of the state's Democratic Congressional delegation held an urgent conference call in which there was "growing consensus" that a Democratic alternative to Mr. Davis must enter the recall race, a participant, Representative Cal Dooley, said.
"There is still time to identify another candidate," Mr. Dooley said, "and I think that we are fortunate that we have a very deep bench of prominent Democrats in this state." 
Ms. Feinstein, speaking from a foreign policy gathering in Aspen, Colo., said she had decided that Mr. Davis deserved a chance to finish his term and that it was more important for her to carry on the business of the United States Senate than to delve into the recall. 
Mr. Davis has strongly opposed the idea of a Democrat running on the so-called replacement part of the recall ballot.
Ms. Feinstein said she was appalled at the "frivolity" of the recall, which has attracted the interest of more than 500 possible candidates, from a pornographer to idle millionaires, describing it as "more like a carnival every day."
"My hope is that this recall causes all of us in California to do some deep soul searching as to whether we really want it to be this way," Ms. Feinstein said in a telephone news conference.
Mr. Davis, in a radio interview before Mr. Schwarzenegger's announcement, was asked about the prospect of running against him. 
"The Terminator!" the governor said on KGO-AM. "I just don't want to comment. But let me just say this. People have rued the day when they said they want to run against someone. A lot of people have been excited about the potential of running against someone and found out that they turned out to be the ultimate loser in the contest. So be careful what you wish for in this business."
Throughout the day, the disarray among the Democrats was palpable. The state party chairman, Art Torres, and the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Terry McAuliffe, who have stood by Mr. Davis on the recall, canceled a news conference this afternoon just minutes before it was scheduled to begin.
The telephone conference call among the Democratic Congressional delegation lasted about 90 minutes and involved about half its 33 members, Mr. Dooley said. Among the potential candidates most frequently mentioned in the discussion were Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante and Leon E. Panetta, a former California congressman and chief of staff to President Bill Clinton, Mr. Dooley said.
Though both men have expressed opposition to the recall and have indicated no intention to run on the replacement ballot, there was considerable speculation today that they might be open to a draft, particularly with the entry of a celebrity like Mr. Schwarzenegger.
Mr. Davis and his supporters were dealt another potentially devastating blow when Ms. Feinstein said in the telephone news conference that although she opposed a Democrat's stepping in, she would not try to dissuade one from doing so.
"I don't see that as my role," she said. "I have said what I think about that. The only way to keep them off is to tie their hands behind their back so they couldn't' sign the papers."
In his radio interview, Mr. Davis reiterated his opposition to a prominent Democrat's stepping in.
"To the extent that the Democrats get into the race," Mr. Davis said, "it makes it look like a normal election and legitimates what is really an effort by the right wing to steal back an election they couldn't win last November." 
But with the deadline of Saturday for candidates to file as a possible successor to Mr. Davis, some members of the state's Democratic delegation in Congress interpreted the timing of Ms. Feinstein's announcement as a green light for them to search for a contender.
"There is growing apprehension about the ability of Governor Davis to defeat the recall," Mr. Dooley said. "I think Senator Feinstein understands the interest among some of the Democratic leaders in California to consider other candidates for the recall and thus made her decision in order to allow consideration of the other candidates."
Ms. Feinstein was also openly critical of Mr. Davis's insistence on labeling the recall as a right-wing conspiracy. She said it was off the mark to characterize Representative Darrell Issa, the San Diego Republican who financed the signature gathering, as right-wing extremist. 
She said Mr. Davis would be able to defeat the effort to oust him only if he began to talk about his strengths.
"It is a sales strategy from the get-go," Ms. Feinstein said. "I mean Darrell Issa, I don't think is a right-wing coup. He may be a right-winger who spent a lot of money and wanted to short-cut to the governor's office himself, no more, no less."
At a news conference after his television appearance, Mr. Schwarzenegger also criticized Mr. Davis's strategy. "He can run a dirty campaign better than anyone, but he can't run a state," Mr. Schwarzenegger said. "In the end, it is my duty to jump into the race and to bring hope to the people."
Mr. Schwarzenegger, who has no political experience other than leading a successful statewide ballot initiative last fall on after-school programs, blamed California's politicians for the state's problems. The effort to oust Mr. Davis has been largely fueled by unhappiness with the state's economic woes, which included a $38 billion budget deficit.
To interspersed applause and cheers from the studio audience, Mr. Schwarzenegger said there was a "total disconnect" between ordinary people and elected officials.
"And what that means basically is the people are doing their jobs," he said. "The people are working hard, the people are paying their taxes, the people are raising their families. The politicians are not doing their jobs."
In an interview today in Aspen, where Ms. Feinstein has spent the week at a foreign policy conference and relaxing at her log house on a mesa overlooking the Aspen Valley, she said that she believed that Mr. Davis could survive the recall, but she acknowledged that he faced an uphill battle.
"I think it is tough, but I think he can sustain a 'no' vote on recall, if he lets people see him being decisive, solving problems, acting gubernatorial," she said. She argued that "there is an obvious choice," because Mr. Davis "was elected governor with seven million votes just nine months ago."
She said she gave the question of running "a lot of thought" but decided in the end that her Senate seniority was too important to give up. "So I am going to stay the course," she said.
Earlier in the day, Ms. Huffington, a populist author and syndicated columnist, officially announced her candidacy for governor. Ms. Huffington said she would not have entered the race if Ms. Feinstein had decided to present herself as the Democratic alternative. "I'm not interested in splitting the vote," she said.
An independent, Ms. Huffington made no bones about her disdain for both the Republicans and Democrats, calling them fanatics and fools.
"California is in deep, deep trouble," she said. "Its citizens deserve more than the partisan, petty and pathetic leadership it's getting at the moment."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Arianna Huffington talked yesterday about her candidacy.; Arnold Schwarzenegger said yesterday that he would be a candidate for governor of California. He declared his candidacy on the "Tonight" show with Jay Leno. Gov. Gray Davis faces a recall election on Oct. 7. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)(pg. A18)

HEADLINE: Northwest Chief Says Airline Will Not File for Bankruptcy 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: ROMULUS, Mich., Aug. 6 

 BODY:
Northwest Airlines, which warned unions in the spring that it would have to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if workers did not grant nearly $1 billion in wage and benefit concessions, said today that a bankruptcy filing would not be necessary.
 That does not mean the airline has given up on obtaining cutbacks. Indeed, company executives reiterated their need to reduce wages and benefits to levels achieved at other large carriers like United Airlines, American Airlines and US Airways. 
 United and US Airways obtained concessions from their employees after filing for bankruptcy protection last year, while American's unions granted wage and benefit cuts in the face of the airline's threat to do so. US Airways has since emerged from bankruptcy, and United is preparing a revamping plan. 
However, Richard H. Anderson, the chief executive of Northwest, said in an interview today that the airline was not headed toward a bankruptcy filing. "We're going to continue to manage the airline," he said, "and get it restructured appropriately without a Chapter 11."
Mr. Anderson's comments came as Northwest unveiled the first of a new fleet of Airbus A330 jets at Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport, one of its major hubs. The planes, which will eventually replace the McDonnell-Douglas DC-10 and join the Boeing 747 on international flights, are up to 40 percent more efficient than those planes and can carry more passengers, executives said.
Mr. Anderson rankled Northwest's unions in April, when he said the airline would be forced to join United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, and US Airways in seeking bankruptcy protection unless workers granted $950 million in wage and benefit cuts by July 1.
At the time, analysts questioned Mr. Anderson's contention, citing Northwest's relatively healthy cash position, which it has maintained despite steep declines in traffic to Asia, where it has a significant presence along with United.
Unions refused to grant the cuts, and the deadline passed without any comment from the airline about a bankruptcy filing. Indeed, Mr. Anderson acknowledged today that the airline had been able to maintain its liquidity in the face of many challenges, from the Sept. 11 attacks to the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS. Since 2000, Northwest has cut its annual costs by $1.4 billion and reduced its operations by 15 percent.
"In the last two and a half years, we've been the most aggressive in the industry in terms of getting out in front of the problems that we faced," Mr. Anderson said. "It's necessitated some very hard decisions."
Northwest lost $160 million in the second quarter, before one-time government reimbursements for security fees. Nonetheless, it ended the second quarter with $2.9 billion in cash, which translated to 30 percent of the last 12 months of revenue, said the airline's president, Douglas M. Steenland. Even with labor concessions, Mr. Steenland estimated that United's cash was equal to 12 percent of its revenue, while American's cash translated to 11 percent of revenue. Mr. Steenland said the airline was continuing to discuss the proposed cuts with union officials but declined to say when he thought the discussions might yield results. Both he and Mr. Anderson were pessimistic about the immediate future for the major airlines, which have been buffeted by the weak economy and challenged by competition from low-fare carriers. "We don't see any end in sight," Mr. Steenland said. "We don't see any light at the end of the tunnel yet."
Mr. Anderson, in the interview, said traffic to Asia in August would continue to be down in the double-digit range because of the after-effects of the SARS outbreak. "I hope we don't have a wave of locusts," he said he recently told employees. "We've had war, and we've had plague, I guess," he added, referring to SARS, "and terrorism, and we seem to have sort of one event after another."
In fact, the airline had two more issues to contend with today. Mr. Anderson said the airline would be hurt by the government's decision to suspend two programs that allowed passengers to connect through American airports on the way to other countries without visas. He said that would primarily affect Northwest's flights from Minneapolis and Detroit to destinations in Canada. The cost of lost business from visa-less passengers who are forced to cancel flights would be in the millions of dollars, he said, declining to be more specific.
Also today, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers filed suit over Northwest's refusal to buy back 4.8 million shares of preferred stock that were issued to workers a decade ago in return for contract concessions. The airline was supposed to repurchase the shares, worth $225 million, by Aug. 1, and said in June that it would pay for them in cash.
But last week, Northwest said it was not permitted to buy the shares under the law in Delaware, where it is incorporated, and would instead pay dividends on the stock. In the suit, filed in New York State Supreme Court, the union, which represents customer service and reservations agents at the airline, sought immediate repayment of at least $100 million. 
"Our members fulfilled all their obligations under the agreement," said Robert Roach, the union's general vice president for transportation. "Northwest Airlines must live up to its commitments and provide what rightfully belongs to our members. This is a bill that is due, and a bill that must be paid." Northwest said it would not comment on the suit.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "THE AMERICAN EFFECT: GLOBAL PERSPECTIVES ON THE UNITED STATES, 1990-2003," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street (212) 570-3676 (through Oct. 12). Exploring ways that artists throughout the world react to the United States as a superpower, this show of documentary films, videos, installations, photographs, paintings and objects by 47 artists and filmmakers and 3 collaborative groups runs from sunny side up to deep despair. There are reflections on America's military might, its industrial clout, its treatment of minorities, its consumerism, its justice system, its marketing strategies, its religious evangelism, its celebrity worship and its interference with other governments. On the other hand there are more positive expressions of admiration for the freedoms, the opportunities and the material achievements of a country unfettered by ancient traditions. The show has its weak spots but overall is provocative and visually compelling. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"ANSEL ADAMS AT 100," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Nov. 3). This exhibition of 113 of Adams's photographs, in celebration of the 100th anniversary of his birth, has been traveling around the world for two years. In these warehouse galleries it has a strangely random and homely feel. The photographs look small and lost. Maybe it's the setting. Maybe it's because the show, organized roughly thematically -- austere peaks, plants, peaks with plants, grand vistas, rocks -- doesn't have a clearly focused concept. Or maybe it's because the curator wanted to tamp down Adams's bombast and replace it with something quieter, smaller and subtler. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays to 7:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Sarah Boxer).

* "ART OF THE FIRST CITIES: THE THIRD MILLENNIUM B.C. FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN TO THE INDUS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). The most timely exhibition in years, as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful. It surveys the culture of the third millennium B.C., mainly centered in Mesopotamia, the crucible of Sumerian civilization, where art, architecture, law and writing developed with the rise of the earliest cities. The beginnings of a cosmopolitan art are in tiny cylinder seals and in figurines. The show is full of small objects that are monumental in concept. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* MAX BECKMANN, Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 29). Like Beckmann, this retrospective of that German genius is dense, frequently revelatory and exhausting: -- all that heavy-handed symbolism and claustrophobia. Beckmann can seem like a truculent master, glaring balefully at us from his self-portraits, disappointed by our moral turpitude. It is easy to get bogged down in the miasma of his obscure allusions. But he also puts brush to canvas with surprising tenderness. Color is luxurious, not garish. The humor is sly and black. Finally, he is unavoidably compelling. Hours and admission: See above. (Kimmelman).

* "BLACK PRESIDENT: THE ART AND LEGACY OF FELA ANIKULAPO-KUTI," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 28). The Nigerian composer, musician and activist Fela Kuti (1938-1997) invented the musical style called Afrobeat, relentlessly assailed political corruption and repression in Africa and beyond through his records and performances, and led a scandalous private life very publicly. This taut, vivacious exhibition is less about the man himself than about how 30 contemporary artists, most of them African or African-American, respond to his blazing, goading lodestar presence. Their reactions range from celebratory to critical, and few are simple, but his vision of a rejuvenated Africa still shines bright. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"CUBA ON THE VERGE: AN ISLAND IN TRANSITION," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). Is it possible for anyone to photograph Cuba without some sort of romance creeping in? The concept behind this show of Cuban, Cuban-American and American photographers was to eschew "cliched images of vintage American cars and other remnants of a prerevolutionary era" and instead to "convey Cuba present," as the show's guest curator, Terry McCoy, writes in the catalog. But some of the photographs suggest that even as Cuba sinks deeper into poverty, ruin and prostitution, the romance of faded beauty and glamorous revolution won't go away. The most refreshing shots are those in which subjects confront the camera and the fantasy. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+ (Boxer).

"SALVADOR DALI: DREAM OF VENUS," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Sept. 7). While images of the 1939 New York World's Fair in Queens remain ingrained in the American collective memory, one attraction, relegated to the "Amusement Zone," was largely forgotten until now: Dali's "Dream of Venus," a tacky Surrealist fun house with live, semi-nude women. This exhibition consists mainly of photographs that document the project from start to finish. Featuring the handsome, charismatic artist; his enigmatic wife, Gala; and lots of voluptuous, unclothed models, this show and its catalog tell a fascinating tale of idealism, opportunism, provocation and censorship. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 55+ (Ken Johnson).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th century Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Johnson).

* "DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF LEWIS CARROLL," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). A photograph is at least as much a looking glass as it is a window. We see in it our own reflections and obsessions. A post-Freudian world has inevitably come to see C. L. Dodgson's photographs through the looking glass of his alter ego, Lewis Carroll. This provocative show tries to put Dodgson's pictures back in their context, to stress that we have lost touch with Victorian conventions, which Dodgson largely obeyed when he photographed little girls. Childhood to Victorians represented, as the show's curator puts it, an "alternate reality, a metaphysical state of preknowledge." Dodgson, he adds "could pose his charges in adult roles, give them guns, daggers and exotic costumes, even portray them as odalisques and half-dressed waifs, because he and most of his audience believed so emphatically in their total insulation from the implications of such postures." These presentations do not so much underscore the latent sexuality of the child (as we post-Freudians would have it) as they do an obvious lack of it." Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "FROM EXPRESSIONISM TO THE BAUHAUS: HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Sept. 15). Borrowed from the Museum of Modern Art, this economical, powerfully resonant exhibition of German Modernist artworks from the first third of the 20th century includes Expressionist paintings by Ludwig Kirchner, Otto Mueller and Emil Nolde; mordantly satiric New Realist paintings by George Grosz and Otto Dix; and sumptuously elegant utilitarian objects by Marcel Breuer and Marianne Brandt. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"FROM PICASSO TO POLLOCK: CLASSICS OF MODERN ART," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 28). This selective anthology of perennial in-house favorites in a major museum has much to be said for it. The bait is irresistible, the promised classics turn up here and there, and both the young and the not-so-young have a fine time on the ramps. In addition to fine examples by Kandinsky, Picasso, Leger, Chagall, Kokoschka and Malevich, there is an enormous piece in ceramic tiles by Joan Miro. Begun in 1965 and finished in 1967, it is largely in black and white, but every touch of color sings out. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for students and 65+ (John Russell).

* "HENDRICK GOLTZIUS, DUTCH MASTER (1558-1617): DRAWINGS, PRINTS AND PAINTINGS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 7). Goltzius (1558-1617) was one of the hottest of hotshot Dutch artists. He was particularly celebrated for his engravings, many of them mythological tableaus of pumped-up gods and pinup goddesses, rendered in the Mannerist way with flabbergasting elan. But he was also one of the greatdraftsmen of his age -- his landscape drawings prefigure Rembrandt and Ruisdael -- and became a virtuosic painter whose primary subject was bare human flesh: its texture, its color, its chemistry. To some eyes he remains strictly a period artist; to others he connects to the present in interesting ways. The Met show offers the raw materials for both reactions. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "LANDSCAPE OF MEMORY: THE ART OF MU XIN," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400 (through Sept. 7.) The artist and writer Mu Xin, born into a wealthy aristocratic family in China, received a classical scholar's education and early exposure to Western culture. Targeted as a dissident during the Cultural Revolution, he was held in solitary confinement for 18 months, and he secretly wrote a series of first-person meditations now called "Prison Notes," which he carried out of jail sewn in his clothes. Under house arrest several years later, he executed a remarkable series of small landscape paintings in which traditional Chinese themes meet Leonardo da Vinci. The paintings and some of "Prison Notes" are brought together in this lean, penumbral exhibition, organized by the Yale University Art Gallery and the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"LEGENDS OF OUR TIMES: NATIVE RANCHING AND RODEO LIFE ON THE PLAINS AND THE PLATEAU," National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through March 7). This lively account of man, woman and horse among the native people in western reaches of the United States and Canada proves that a cowboy can be an Indian, and vice versa. The show depicts native peoples not as objects of exploitation by the white man but as ranchers, cowboys, entertainers and rodeo performers. It displays more than 700 objects -- saddles, bead and quill works, paintings, photographs, blankets, clothing, horse gear, hunting implements, roundup equipment, headdresses and other ceremonial garb -- from the 18th century to now. At least half of this huge show provides an engaging and comprehensive account of rodeo, but nonrodeo fans will probably have more fun with the bedazzlement of objects depicting the more traditional side of American Indian life. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free (Glueck).

"MANET AND THE AMERICAN CIVIL WAR: THE BATTLE OF U.S.S. KEARSARGE AND C.S.S. ALABAMA," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). Along with many of his countrymen, the thoroughly French painter Edouard Manet was fascinated by a celebrated battle of the American Civil War that took place off Cherbourg in 1864: the fight between the Union sailing ship U.S.S. Kearsarge and the Confederate raider C.S.S. Alabama. Although he missed the battle itself, which ended in victory for the Kearsarge, he was inspired to make an imaginary rendition of it, and several weeks later, visiting the victorious Kearsarge at anchor off Boulogne, he painted the ship itself at first hand. His innovative paintings, with their striking compositional effects and fresher, freer brushwork, had an influence on other artists of the period, notably Monet, Whistler and Courbet. They are on view with other material bearing on the incident: photographs, memorabilia and paintings by others (among them a stunner by Monet). A bold depiction of the sea and ships, very different from the tight, literal renderings of more conventional marine artists, Manet's work helped lead the way to the radical brushwork of Impressionism. Hours and admission: See above.(Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

TONY FOSTER, "Watermarks," James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Aug. 23). Mr. Foster is yet another Englishman whose art revolves around travel. Finding his way from South American tropical forests to glaciers in Greenland, he neatly documents what he sees in watercolor; he then adds found objects like bones, shells, vials of water, rocks and feathers. The art in the gallery is not as adventurous as the artist himself seems to be (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

"H2O," Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through Aug. 22). For obvious reasons a lot of summer group shows take water as a theme, this one more directly and more effectively than most. Works by more than 30 artists include Sally Mann's mysterious photograph of three naked, nubile girls urinating; a piece of magic illusionism by Amy Jenkins that has a bathing woman video-projected into a miniature bathtub; Laura Aguilar's portrait of her own mountainously corpulent self lying naked next to a small rock pool; and a gigantically enlarged sweat gland reproduced in rubber by Jeanne Silverthorne (Johnson).

BEN POLSKY, "Siteunseen," Luxe, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 404-7455 (through Aug. 16). Mr. Polsky's extra-large drawings on heavy sheets of paper are appealing, though overly indebted to Toba Khedoori. With a near miniaturist touch he makes densely detailed images of ruined buildings and rubble by drawing through carbon paper. Surrounded by smudgy expanses of paper, these images have a mournful, disembodied quality (Johnson).

"PUDDLE-WONDERFUL," Artemis Greenberg Van Doren, 730 Fifth Avenue, (212) 445-0444 (through Aug. 15). If this eight-artist show has a theme, it remains obscure. The exhibition includes one of Felix Gonzalez-Torres's memorial piles of candy; quasi-scientific, politically suggestive photographs by Francis Alys, which document people standing in the shadow of a big flagpole in a Mexican square; wind-blown trees video-projected on a gold canvas to magically illusionistic effect, by Donald Moffet; and a melting wax abstraction applied to the gallery skylight by Ferran Martin (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"ASSUME VIVID ASTRO FOCUS VII," Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300 (through Aug. 15). In its seventh installation incarnation, Assume Vivid Astro Focus, as the Brazilian artist Eli Sudbrack prefers to be known, takes Pop-Nouveau multicultural sensory overload to new extremes, with profuse stick-on prints covering most available surfaces, an irresistible music video and enough collaborations with and by other artists to qualify as a group show that is part chapel, part disco and part tattoo parlor. Whatever he is called, Mr. Sudbrack may be the 21st century's Andy Warhol (Roberta Smith).

"FROM GASLIGHTS TO TELEVISION," Susan Teller, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-7335 (through Aug. 28). Typewriters, stoves, refrigerators, clocks, pumps, sewing machines, telephones, fans, ice cream makers, irons and other labor-saving devices turn up in this surprising show about appliances in 20th-century American domestic life. From John Sloan's sexy etching of a woman turning off the light before joining her lover in bed to Louise Leech's painting of her teenage daughters watching the first Moon landing on television, the show conjures an engagingly humane vision of living with modern technology (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

ANSEL ADAMS, "100 + 1," Robert Mann, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 989-2947 (through Aug. 22). Great modern artist or purveyor of high-toned kitsch? Coinciding with the retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, this substantial show affords a fine occasion to weigh the evidence. Looking at Adams's skillfully manipulated, Wild West landscapes, one feels less awakened to the wondrous complexities of photography and nature than bludgeoned by a proto-Spielbergian romanticism (Johnson).

"BOYS OF SUMMER," ClampArt, 531 West 25th Street, (646) 230-0020 (through Sept. 6). If you like to look at men, and you're passing by, stop in. Standing out among the crowd of pictures by more than two dozen photographers are "Bruce in His Car," a 1981 portrait of a skinny bohemian in his big red convertible by Nan Goldin; a beefy, shirtless young football player celebrating with his team, by Brian Finke; men in leather, by Barbara Nitke; and, by Malerie Marder, a large color image of a mixed-sex group of naked people relaxing in a California bathhouse (Johnson).

"FRANKENSTEIN (OR IT'S ALL FUN AND GAMES UNTIL SOMEONE LOSES AN EYE)," Tanya Bonakdar, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 414-4144, (through Aug. 22). Organized by Ethan Sklar, the gallery's director, this exhibition examines the ways artists subvert the physical and decision-making processes of art making by using machines, accident, science, random selection and all-inclusiveness and has a title perfectly suited to its sometimes scary weirdness (Smith).

RACHEL HARRISON, HIRSCH PERLMAN, DIETER ROTH, JACK SMITH, REBECCA WARREN, Matthew Marks, 523 West 24th Street, (212) 243-0200 (through Aug. 15). This show by European and American artists from different generations pays tribute to the ability to conjure loony, often sexual excess from next to nothing in terms of materials or techniques. A museum-quality effort organized by Jeffrey Peabody, the gallery's director, it sings the body electric in clay, found materials, altered stuffed animals and photography (Smith).

* "IN FULL VIEW," Andrea Rosen, 525 West 24th Street, (212) 627-6000 (through Sept. 13). A show that invites visitors on a pluralistic treasure hunt for 18 artworks that tease one's limits of visual perception. Look for Christopher Chiappa's Ford Taurus gas-tank door built into the wall; Maurizio Cattelan's roosting stuffed pigeons; Vincent Shine's tiny, gold Brancusian wasp; Jim Hodges's jewelry-chain spiderweb and Charles Ray's classic "Rotating Disc" (Johnson).

"LIGHT AS AIR," Fischbach, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 759-2345 (through Aug. 22). Most remarkable of all in this 26-artist show is Victoria Gitman's actual-size picture of a moth-shaped silver brooch, its extremely fine filigree painted with eye-straining exactitude. Kevin King's painting of two white swans flying low at a man on railroad tracks is haunting; George Nick's picture of a Victorian house is juicy; and Meg Shields's small painting of an ordinary neighborhood with water tanks towering in the background is nostalgic but not sentimental (Johnson).

ANDREI MOLODKIN, Kashya Hildebrand, 531-539 West 25th Street, (212) 366-5757 (through Sept. 13). This skillful Russian draftsman has a heavy-handed way with popular and political symbols. He draws giant parodies of "I Love N.Y." or "I Love Sex" bumper stickers, replacing the valentine heart with anatomically accurate skulls. Also on view is a double portrait of Lenin and Stalin. What's most interesting is not the imagery but how these enormous drawings are made: entirely with a blue ballpoint pen (Johnson).

CARTER POTTER, "New Film Paintings," Julie Saul, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-2410 (through Aug. 15). Mr. Potter's "paintings" consist of yards of found movie stock stretched in horizontal bands around wooden frames. Including lengths of pure color, sequences of Disney cartoons and lots of illegible imagery, they glow like stained-glass windows while toying with Modernist abstraction, the cult of cinema and the promises and disappointments of new technology (Johnson)

JAMEL SHABAZZ, "Last Sunday in June," Kravets/Wehby, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 352-2238 (through Aug. 15). Mr. Shabazz is the best kind of photojournalist: one driven simply by curiosity about other human beings. His pictures of the annual Gay Pride Parade participants, most in color, are like snapshots in a generously inclusive family album. All kinds pose happily for the camera: a pair of handsome black men dressed like twin schoolboys in white caps and shorts and mint-green shirts; a trio costumed to look like the Andrews Sisters; five laughing lesbians gathered as if at a college reunion (Johnson).

"SPLIT," Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, (646) 336-7183 (through Sept. 6). The best thing in this six-person show is Xavier Veilhan's bigger-than-life skeleton woven in wicker; it slouches casually in a corner of the gallery, a marvel of exotic faux-folk art. Note, too, a dense mix of cartoon characters and abstract patterning painted collaboratively in gouache by Christian Schumann and Gary Panter (Johnson).

JONATHAN TORGOVNIK, "Bollywood Dreams," Klotz/Sirmon, 511 West 25th Street, (212) 741-4764 (through Aug. 15). An accomplished photojournalist realizes his fascination with the world of Indian cinema -- better known as Bollywood -- in big, documentary color pictures. Mr. Togovnik's jam-packed images of moviegoers, actors, billboards and theaters mix the sacred and the profane with alternately fabulous and heartbreaking results (Johnson).

"VACATION," Spike, 547 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4100 (through Sept. 20). Innocence and experience collide in the works of Norm Magnusson, who outlines juvenile, coloring-book-style images over gridded fields of pages from pointedly selected books. Jesus offering guidance to a little boy is drawn over pages from Bulfinch's "Mythology," for example, and paper-doll clothes over "Lolita." Also on view: Buck Henri's engaging photographs of exotic dancers, old cars, mannequins, small-town parades and other subjects; Alan Schmer's illustrative paintings of farm animals; and Melissa Stern's pedestal-size figurative sculptures that blend surrealism and primitivism (Johnson).

Other Galleries

OLAV WESTPHALEN, "The First Long Island City Blimp Derby," Sculpture Center, 44-19 Purves Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 361-1750 (through Aug. 16). The Blimp Derby, produced by Mr. Westphalen, took place on June 28. You can still see the track painted on the floor where contestants steered their ungainly, remote-control miniature dirigibles; the lumpy, handmade and clumsily painted silver winner's trophy; and painted on one wall in delicate gray washes, an advertisement for the race sponsor, Budweiser (Johnson).

"DIRT WIZARD," Brooklyn Fire Proof, 101 Richardson Street, at Leonard Street, Williamsburg, (718) 302-4702 (through Aug. 18). Organized by the artist Kathy Grayson, this ambitious show of paintings, drawings and wall paintings uses the work of emerging artists like Keegan McHargue, Matt Leines, Maya Hayuk, Xylor Jane and Justin Samson. It highlights the graffiti-based drawing wizardry emanating from the East and West Coasts, as well as a spiritual and stylistic meeting of East and West in the global sense (Smith).

Last Chance

"BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG CITY," David Zwirner Gallery, 525 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2070 (through today). This dense, wildly eclectic exhibition of art from the 1980's and early 90's is a memento mori to the fleetingness of time, fame and in some cases talent. It is based on the third issue of the magazine Charley, whose pages are culled from the art magazines and catalogs of the period (Smith).

TODD KNOPKE, "Group Sh/Deep Down," I-20 Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 645-1100 (through tomorrow). The two best things in Mr. Knopke's cheerfully fragmented show are a crude, life-size sculpture of five white, life-size wolves sitting in a tree, based on a psychoanalytic patient's dream famously written about by Freud, and a miniature closet built into the gallery wall at floor level. An 18-inch-tall bookcase filled with tiny volumes hinges open to reveal an electrically lighted interior with wire coat hangers, a polished, hardwood floor and a revolving disco ball (Johnson).

ELLEN KOOI, "(where the grass is green . . .)," P.P.O.W., 555 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 647-1044 (through today). The big, glossy, staged photograph made popular by Gregory Crewdson has reached retirement age, but the best of this Dutch artist's efforts are still divertingly dreamy, especially those of kneeling women shouting into curbside street drains or of a long line of people emerging from the sea (Johnson).

* "NOW PLAYING," D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212)352-9460 (through today). This lively, don't-miss show combines three up-to-the-minute guest impresarios, Scott Hug, John Connolly and Daniel Reich. The collectivist spirit afoot blithely mixes media into environments. Gender-bending sex is pervasive. The operative analogy is a treasure hunt. Allusions fly to cartoons, fashion, hip-hop, television, neo-punk culture, pornography and Chinese landscape painting, with the 1960's a touchstone, consciously or otherwise, but the 60's through the darkening lens of later decades. Craft is slyly sold: the affect of slapdash construction belies studious art school craftsmanship and even the prevalence of a certain technical, market-conscious fussiness (Kimmelman).

"ONLINE," Feigen Contemporary, 535 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-0500 (through tomorrow). Not about Web art but about the traditional use of line, this 38-artist show includes too much that is only tangentially linear. But works like Daniel Zeller's intense fields resembling a zany topographical map, Hilary Harkness's fantasy of sexy female sailors drawn with Ingres-like refinement and Beth Campbell's branching diagram of her possible futures suggest that a more focused investigation of the varieties of linear expression in contemporary art would be worth pursuing (Johnson).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Oskar Schlemmer's art in "From Expressionism to the Bauhaus." (Photo by Museum of Modern Art); Last Chance: "Now Playing," a group show at D'Amelio Terras, looks back at the 1960's through the darkening lens of later decades. (Photo by D'Amelio Terras)
